results.description:
This Hike was postponed from 4/9 to 4/16 because of weather.

RSVP Here: http://www.njyp.org/events/hike-south-mountain-climb-7

Buy Tix Here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hike-south-mountain-climb-tickets-22710876844

In the heart of Suburbia lies a beautiful piece of land set aside for us to explore. While it is in the middle of Millburn, West Orange and South Orange, you would never know after just a few minutes of hiking within! Witness 2 waterfalls, giant Rhododendrons and a pretty riverside walk as part of the adventure. Afterward those who have worked up an appetite will head out for lunch together.

Specs: Difficulty level is 2.5, http://www.njyp.org/page/hike-ratings
5 miles and will take about 3 hours.
As with all hikes you must be in reasonable athletic shape.

Member Cost: $7 first 5 online, $10 online, $20 at the door (so please register online)

Non-Member Cost: $15 online, $20 at the door

Note: Being in the MeetUp group does not make you an NJYP member. You must set up a profile, pay dues, and be approved at <a>www.NJYP.org.</a> If you are not a member, you must select the non-member price or become a member first. 


Tickets: There are a limited number of Tickets for sale. Tickets are not mailed, but your name will be kept at the door. Actual hike is subject to change depending on weather conditions, fallen trees, etc. All sales are final.

Sweeper: If the group is large we are going to look for 2 volunteers to act as sweepers. Sweepers will walk at the end of the hike line and will make sure the group stays together.

Hike Leader: DAVID will be leading this hike.

What to bring:
Hiking boots or sneakers
2 Liters of Water (required).
Snacks, a light lunch, etc.
Toilet paper, tissues, plastic bags for garbage, etc.

Inclement Weather:
Most heavy precipitation will cancel this hike; drizzle may not. Please check your inbox for updates. Tickets will be refunded.

Directions:
Take 280 West until exit 10 (West Orange / Northfield Ave). At the end of the ramp, make a left onto Northfield Ave. Follow for approx 2.4 miles and bear right just past the dunkin donuts on the right hand side (you’ll see a sign that shows an arrow pointing to right saying Verona, and it’s a 1 way street). Follow that 1 way to the end and make a left. That will put you on Cherry Lane. Follow that for almost a mile and then look for the Tulip Springs parking area sign on the left hand side of the road. Pull into the 2nd parking area, about 200 feet to the right after you turn in.

http://maps.google.com/maps?q=40.756181,-74.291525&num=1&sll=40.757756,-74.291723&sspn=0.006295,0.006295&ie=UTF8&ll=40.757756,-74.291723&spn=0.012044,0.014141&z=16&iwloc=A

How to find the group:
Meet in the 2nd parking lot. When you turn off the main road into the Tulip Springs parking area, the 2nd lot is to the right about 200 ft.
We will not wait for latecomers.
results.name: Hike: South Mountain Climb

results.description:
AngularJS is an open-source Javascript framework, maintained by Google, that assists with running single-page applications. Its goal is to augment browser-based applications with model-view-controller (MVC) capability, in an effort to make both development and testing easier.

Learn the fundamentals and guiding principles of Angular and how to build single page applications while learning about key Angular topics such as directives, filters, data binding, scope, modules, routes, factories, services and more.

Logistics

Date: April 16, 2016

Time: 10:30-4:30pm

Price: $125 (Purchase Tickets Here)

Prerequisites

A laptop 

Sublime Text or some other text editor

Google Chrome or some other web browser

Node.js Installed on your computer

Refund Policy: All refunds must be requested 7 days before the event.

results.description:
Free with suggested donation of $1 or $2 dollars to defray your organizer's expenses.  RSVP's begin Friday, April 1st at 1:00pm.


Meetup location is by the C Town supermarket on the corner right, close to the subway exit. Optional lunch after the walk - we'll end convenient to the subway:  N train at 8th Avenue and 62nd Street.

Sunset Park is a refreshing change of pace from the hustle and bustle of Manhattan and the more popular Brooklyn neighborhoods.  Once home to the Canarsee Indians and then the Dutch in the 1600's, the area was  been settled by Italian, Irish, Polish and Scandanavians in the 1800's and early 20th century. 

Nowadays the area has vibrant Latin American and Chinese communities and even a brand new waterfront park amid an industrial zone that has just opened after a decade of construction and challenges.   We'll end our walk in Brooklyn's Chinatown and take in some local cuisine as an lunch option afterwards around 1:30pm. Along our journey we'll see some distinctive urban housing, views from atop Sunset Park, and a bit of the extraordinary Greenwood Cemetery, the final resting place of countless luminaries. Note this meetup entails a fair amount of walking, a good 4 miles with some uphill. You may want to bring a sandwich or snack.  We'll also be passing by a very cool bakery early in the walk.

Optional Dim Sum at the end of the walk at Sunset Park's most popular eatery.

results.description:
Come and Celebrate Spring painting the glorious Cherry Blossoms of Central Park! Whether you have a done a little painting or are a seasoned painter, this workshop is for you- as all participants are assisted 'one on one', to suit their level of experience.

During this workshop professional artist Danielle Hatherley will be producing her own painting alongside all students, discussing each step in the process along the way. She will explain all of the fundamentals of painting including composition, color mixing and tonal assessment.

Danielle's teaching style is very hands on. Students receive a lot of direct personal assistance in between the various steps of her demonstration piece.

Date: Saturday, April 16, 2016

Start time: 10:30 am

Finish time: 5:30 pm

Cost: $119 for students bringing own materials
           $149 for those wishing to have all equipment supplied (includes a canvas, the use of an easel, brushes, paints, medium and all other materials required to produce a painting)
*The day includes a couple of breaks as required.

***PLEASE READ BELOW- IMPORTANT INFORMATION***

ADVANCE PAYMENT IS REQUIRED. If you would like to join us, please reply via the RSVP link. YOU MUST THEN MAKE YOUR PAYMENT WITHIN 24 HOURS OF MAKING YOUR RSVP. Please follow the green link below to make your online payment. Your RSVP is only confirmed with ADVANCE payment.  Payment, will not be accepted on the day, under any circumstances.

You should ONLY rsvp YES if you intend on coming to this Meetup. If you are not sure, please do not rsvp until you are sure.  If you have any questions, please email Danielle and she will answer them.  If you rsvp YES and pay, and then change your mind, you should revert your rsvp to 'not going' (and email Danielle if you need to).  

*Cancellations are accepted (and refunds given) up to 48 hours before the commencement of the workshop.  Thereafter all bookings are final.

You can make your online payment via this link... 

https://squareup.com/market/the-plein-air-painting-school

Want to know what students of Danielle's have to say? Read some of her testimonials on the 'About' page of this meetup group and some of our past meetup reviews.

* Below are a few photos from our previous Cherry Blossom workshops

Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

results.description:
It is becoming a theme in modern physics...that space-time is not a fundamental quantity, but is rather an emergent phenomenon.  Space-time emerges from the entanglement between degrees of freedom in a non-perturbative description of quantum gravity.

The first bit of the discussion will be somewhat high level...spoken in the language mostly of pictures.  I will briefly review the Rindler spacetime, the temperature of its horizon, and the Beckenstein formula for the entropy of a black hole.  Then I will put them all together in a pictorial representation showing how decreasing the entropy on the two sides of a double-sided black hole pulls apart from each other their respective space-times.

Dr. Jeff Jones will then take over to introduce us to the AdS/CFT correspondence (that's a mouthful...it stands for the anti-deSitter Space Conformal Field Theory correspondence....an even bigger mouthful!). Put simply, itmeans that there is a correspondence between ordinary quantum field theory and gravity....so that when you are doing a quantum problem, there is a complementary description of gravity.

This is leading us to a better understanding of quantum gravity, high temperature superconductivity, and a whole lot more.

Please join us for a fascinating look at the emergence of space-time.

Some references

Popular   https://www.sciencenews.org/article/entanglement-gravitys-long-distance-connection

VanRaamsdonk, the father of this idea....http://arxiv.org/pdf/1005.3035.pdf

https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=WQU9yOtWrQk


Susskind https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9crggox5rbc

The Ryu-Takayangi Formula http://arxiv.org/pdf/hep-th/0603001v2.pdf
results.name: Entanglement: the Glue that Holds Space-time Together

results.description:
Saturday in the Park! What could be better…except a Photo Workshop with popular photo tour leader and Central Park maven Steve Rosenbach!


This is a photo workshop that I carefully designed so as to get the maximum amount of great photo opportunities within about a 3 hour easy walk. I’m limiting the number of people who can attend, so that I can spend time with each of you to help with anything you need in getting really compelling images of the sites that we visit along the way. That can range from basic photo or camera help to assistance with composition and advanced techniques.

Also, as an added value, you'll be able to send me your photos (or links to them) from this workshop for evaluation and feedback. I'll make comments and suggestions, and in many cases, do some photo editing on your photos to demonstrate how to make a good image even better.


Our first stop will be Strawberry Fields, an intimate haven just inside the park set aside as a memorial to John Lennon. From there, we’ll circumnavigate The Lake to take advantage of panoramic views with the elegant skylines of Central Park West or Fifth Avenue in the background.

We’ll “get lost” in The Ramble, a bucolic, forested tract with a picturesque stream and rustic bridges where, for the moment, you can imagine that the city is far away.

Finally, we’ll arrive at Bethesda Terrace, an iconic, romantic plaza that you’ll recognize from countless movies. We’ll explore the Terrace from the grand sweep of its monumental staircases to the intricate carvings of honeybees and birds along its steps.

All together, we'll see 30 unique and photogenic features in the heart of Central Park, and along the way, Steve will regale you with stories of the Park and the specific sites we'll visit. 

It will be a journey that will delight your sense of color, texture, and proportion as well as refresh your spirit.

Note: If you are new to photography or could use a refresher on topics like f-stops, depth of field, basic composition, etc, I will conduct a free pre-tour session on those topics 45 minutes prior to the listed starting time of this photo tour.  Message me once you have signed up if you would like to attend.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be holding a sign near the first park bench closest to the southeast corner of CPW at W. 72nd Street
results.name: Heart of the Park: Central Park Photo Workshop

results.description:
We're going to see "Designing Identity:  The Power of Textiles in Late Antiquity"  at the Institute for Study of the Ancient World. 


"Both the continuity and the extraordinary cultural changes of Late Antiquity are strikingly evident in the textiles in this exhibition. These labor-intensive, costly items would have be­longed to those with sufficient wealth to expend on a display of social standing. Designing Identity explores how the wealthy elite expressed the ideals of self, household, and society through materials, techniques, and the types and decoration of garments and furnishings."


Here's a link to the exhibit:  

http://isaw.nyu.edu/exhibitions/design-identity

And here's a review:


http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/15/science/roman-empire-textiles-archaeology-late-antiquity.html?smprod=nytcore-iphone&smid=nytcore-iphone-share&_r=0

To get acquainted, we'll first meet for coffee a few blocks away, at Starbucks Lex/85.

Then we'll walk over to the exhibit (84th betw Madison/5th).  Admission is free.


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.

results.description:
FIRST MARINA PRACTICE

Please expect this practice to begin after 11am and run later than usual. We are launching boats this day. Message me here via Meetup if you don't see us. Arowana's Dragon Boat season runs through mid-September.

The new members will meet up on the docks promptly approximately 30 minutes before the start time. We will require waivers to be filled out and then start with stretches followed by basic dragon boat paddling technique with you on land. Afterwards, we will take the boat out and paddle. No previous skill required. We will provides life vests and paddles. We recommend bringing a bottle of water, sun screen and wear clothing that you will be OK getting wet, swimwear being best. Shades, gloves and hat are worn by most of our paddlers as well but are not required. Practice lasts roughly 2 hours.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Our practices are on a first-come-first-serve basis. We may or may not be able to accommodate everyone on any given weekend, and there may be a waiting list on the event. Please update your responses if your plans change so that we may make space for those on the wait list.

PLEASE NOTE EARLY SEASON PADDLING WILL BE COLD, BRING A WATERPROOF JACKET!

Sometimes we grab lunch afterward in Flushing, you are welcome to join us.

This series of Meetups is catered to introduction to dragon boat. Our veteran members will be paddling alongside you as well. If you like'd to be added to our team mailing list, please ask Lin or Selene for additional details.

Arowana will be participating in The New York Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival in Corona Park this August and possibly other races during the course of the year.
results.how_to_find_us: Grand Central Parkway to exit 9E OR Van Wyck Expressway to exit 13  follow signs for World's Fair Marina. 7 Train to Willets Point/Mets. Walk North towards the Marina. Look for orange and black shirts. Call 347 545 2260 if you're lost.
results.name: Dragon Boat Practice

Calling all poets! Jersey City Writers is now offering a weekly poetry workshop. 

This workshop will start by critiquing 2-3 poems, one by each person signed up ahead of time. The workshop will end, if time permits, with one 10 minute writing prompt (an idea to incorporate into a poem written on the spot).  Poets who sign up to be workshopped must email Sarah poem by 10am Friday so she can print copies for the group. To sign up for a workshop in advance, please contact Sarah Jewell at [masked]. 

While workshopping poems, we will “mind our P’s and Q’s” by Praising first what works in a poem, and then Questioning what might be improved. This helps to keep the feedback positive and constructive. If you are new to critiquing poetry, please see these guidelines:
http://triadwriters.org/inspiration/guidelines-critique-of-poem/

results.description:
THE THREE POISONS - HATRED

"Without anger there is no enemy...when hatred consumes us, we perceive enemies everywhere."

Pema Chodron

This week we will continue our discussion of the Three Poisons - Delusion and Ignorance, Hatred and Greed - and take a look at Hatred.

In Buddhist thought hatred is one consequence of an error we make.  Instead of understanding that we are interconnected and dependent on each other and and that things constantly change, we believe we are solid, permanent and unchanging "selves" and fundamentally separate from and threatened by "others." Hatred is found on a spectrum from irritation and annoyance to anger, ill-will and rage. It also is expressed in attitudes like resistance, rejection or distraction.

Hatred can arise in response to memories of past events, from any thought or event in the present moment or even from thoughts of an imagined future event. It can arise when someone injures us or someone we love or if we just think they do. It also shows up when someone does something good for someone we already dislike or hate. On the community or global level hatred arises as racial, ethnic or gender violence, or in the extreme, it can culminate in war and genocide.

The challenge, then, is how to express compassion or kindness toward ourselves and other beings. The answer is found in understanding that we do ignore how connected to and dependent on we are to each other. By correcting the misperception of separateness and finding wise balance in our responses to impermanence, we can live more awakened and aware.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: Wheel of Life - Hatred and Loving-Kindness and Compassion

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's  newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at [masked]

Discover all that the American Museum of Natural History has to offer while socializing and exploring its many halls with other fun people from NYSN and other social networking groups.  You will be teamed up with others ( unless you already have a team ) and set out on an afternoon adventure that you won’t forget! The Hunt will take you through the many exhibits at the museum as you look for clues and answers to the questions that we will challenge you with.  The Hunt will take you about 90 Minutes and the team that finds the most the clues will be our winners!  All the teams will gather at a local tavern when you finish where we will tally up the results, eat, drink and socialize!

The Fee includes admission to the museum and the hunt!

Following lunch you are invited to go back to the museum to enjoy all the exhibits at a more leisurely pace

*** CLICK HERE TO PRE-PAY & RESERVE YOUR SPOT*** https://www.eventbrite.com/e/american-museum-of-natural-history-scavenger-hunt-tickets-24378280092

Can I come alone? Yes, we will randomly set you up on teams of 5.

Do I need experience? No, this is easy and fun!

What kinds of things are we looking for? You will be looking for things that are part of the exhibits so you will probably learn a thing or two along the way!

How does it work? The group will meet at The Firehouse Tavern.  We will put you on a team and hand you a sheet with about 30 different clues that you will need to find the answers to in the museum.

What should I wear? It's a weekend, be casual and comfortable.  You will be doing a lot of walking in the museum so wear comfortable shoes.

What to bring: camera or camera phone

*** MUST PRE-PAY TO RESERVE YOUR SPOT ***

What is included?

-Admission to the museum

-Scavenger hunt fee

*** CLICK HERE TO PRE-PAY & RESERVE YOUR SPOT*** https://www.eventbrite.com/e/american-museum-of-natural-history-scavenger-hunt-tickets-24378280092
results.name: American Museum of Natural History Scavenger Hunt

Buen Camino! 

Nina

This is an open house and introduction to Lyndhurst Meditation. This introduction gives hope for those seeking happiness, peace, and truth.

At Lyndhurst Meditation we use a very simple, yet direct way of cleansing and freeing the mind. This meditation is a customized guided one-on-one practice through self-reflection.

Give your mind and heart a break from the chaos of everyday life! Deeply examine and empty your self to find absolute peace and freedom!

If you are interested in becoming a member of our meditation center we will offer a special discounted price for meetup members only! 

We are located at 306 Ridge Rd, Lyndhurst, NJ 07071. Our meditation center is located across the stress from Wendy's. You can park in the front and additional free parking is located in the rear of the building. This introduction will last about an hour to an hour and a half. If you have many plans for the day please say this before the meetup starts so we can accommodate you properly. 

**If you are not able to attend this event, but have an interest in Lyndhurst Meditation you can call our center to have a personal introduction today! Lyndhurst Meditation is a non-profit organization and is tax deductible. A $10 donation is appreciated for the introduction.

results.description:
*************************************

NOTICE - Please support our donation drive to pay for our group's yearly Meetup fees.  Donation info and instructions... http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/messages/boards/thread/49619820

*************************************


Join us on this scrumptious, finger lickin' WINGS n THANGS FOOD CRAWL!!!

This will be a walking tour in Manhattan offering the tastiest and/or most interesting chicken wings, fried chicken, and other thangs around!  Please join us for the fun and feast!  Should I even have to say "please"?  Come'on now - I know we Asians love our chicken wings!!!

Destinations and attractions:

#1 - BonChon - 325 5th Ave New York, NY 10016 (32nd St)

BonChon is the Korean fried chicken standard where we shall begin our gastronomical adventure - known for its perfectly crispy, huge wings, with flavor choices of soy garlic or "hot" (which contains red chili peppers and 'gochugaru,' a smoky Korean spice).

http://32ndstreetny.bonchon.com/

#2 - The Hog Pit NYC - 37 W 26th St New York, NY, 10010 (Bet Ave of Americas & Broadway)

They don’t just dump stuff in a deep-fryer and hope for the best here. The chef has a strict, 10-step process... which he may divulge to you if you ask nicely, and may not if you're all, "Don't be a d*ck; tell me the process". In addition to doing an incredibly solid everyday offering, they’re always doing weird-ass flavors for the fun of it, too, like Thai peanut butter & spicy jelly.

http://static1.squarespace.com/static/539f7d90e4b09ef21bd6a804/t/560ad702e4b030998f9f5d9e/1443550978767/HogPitMenu.pdf

#3 - The Dougnut Plant - 220 W 23rd St, New York, NY 10011 (Bet 8th & 7th)

Let's break up the savory and salty with some sweet treats.  Bustling outlet for handcrafted doughnuts in unusual varieties such as crème brûlée & tres leches since 1994.

http://doughnutplant.com/

#4 - Dan & John's Wings - 135 1st Ave  New York, NY 10003 (St Marks Pl & 9th St)

As their story goes…”Dan & John are two friends from Buffalo who couldn’t find wings they liked in NYC; so, they started making their own.” They began in Smorgasburg, made a name for themselves for their authentic Buffalo wings, and finally opened a brick & mortar shop in NYC.

http://danandjohns.com/wings


Possible #5 - Matcha Cafe Wabi - 233 E 4th St
New York, NY 10009 b/t Avenue B & Avenue A 

Settle down after the feasting and walking for some nice matcha and matcha latte.  We can chat about the day's adventures and tastes.



Cheers!

Will  "Chicken Wing" Fong

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

Join DM Noah Anderson the first D&D 5E Module!

The Sword Coast is under siege. In an audacious bid for power, the Cult of the Dragon, along with its dragon allies and the Red Wizards of Thay, seeks to free Tiamat from her prison in the Nine Hells to bring her to the Forgotten Realms. The cult's forces are sweeping from town to town, laying waste to all who oppose them and gathering a hoard of riches for their dread queen. The threat is so dire, factions as disparate as the Harpers and the Zhentarim are banding together to battle the cult. Never before has the need for heroes been as desperate.

Players of all walks, new and old, are always welcome. Please feel free to comment if you have any questions.

Learn & Sweat Bhangra sessions are for you 

- if you want start your weekend with a bang

- if you love to sweat it out to heart pumping music

- if you think fitness doesn't mean lifting weights

- if you want to learn and groove to energetic Bhangra while burning serious cals.

The class begins with a warm up, high energy and high fun, this Bhangra class combines the strong, festive moves of traditional Bhangra dance with a follow-me fitness-class style. 

Each week participants also have the opportunity to learn a more in-depth piece of Bhangra choreography to a popular dance floor hit. 

If you love Bhangra music and you’re looking for a fun, unique way to keep fit, join us to sweat it out while partying to the beats.

No previous dance experience is necessary - just bring in your smile! Our Instructors are professional, friendly, and open minded. So come on in and let swag emerge!

Wear comfortable clothes and shoes.

The drop-in price is $20 and can be paid here on meetup, or head over to our website www.nycbhangra.com/nycbhangra/signup for other options to pay.

Checkout our other BEGINNER BHANGRA classes too!

results.description:
Brendan's has intricately designed beams and pillars, high overhead archways, a magnificent marble fireplace, long narrow stain glass windows and massive upside down umbrella lighting and impressive wall decorations.  We have eaten here many times before, including the Macy's Flower Show and our holiday party a few years ago.


(212) 564 - 5405

Prices are moderate and you can have lunch ($9 - $16) or a fixed-price brunch including a drink ($18). 

*Menu items for brunch and lunch include sandwiches, pasta, salads, pizza

http://www.brendansbar.com/brunch.htm



***Please bring SMALL BILLS (1's, 5's, 10's) and a $20 bill to help facilitate payment of the check.  Thank you.


AFTER LUNCH...

Morgan Library & Museum    

225 Madison Ave at 36th St 

(212)[masked]    

Morgan Library & Museum began as the private library of financier Pierpont Morgan [masked]), one of the preeminent collectors and cultural benefactors in the United States. Today, it is a complex of buildings in the heart of New York City housing one of the world’s foremost collections of manuscripts, rare books, music, drawings, and ancient and other works of art.

This weekend, on April 15 - 17, The Morgan Library & Museum will celebrate its 10 year anniversary of a landmark expansion project with FREE general admission for all visitors. The acclaimed, Renzo Piano-designed expansion project was completed in April 2006.

The Morgan features several handsomely renovated period rooms, a sophisticated 264-seat performance hall, a 60-seat Education Center, and a spacious glass-enclosed central court, along with many more art galleries and gracious public amenities.


Saturday, April 16th Schedule:


* 10 am - 12 pm Video presentations in Gilder Lehrman Hall featuring Colin B. Bailey, Renzo Piano, and Philippe de Montebello

* 11 am - 3 pm Live classical music in Gilbert Court

* 2 - 3:30 pm Sight Writing: A Conversation with Nina Katchadourian, Jonathan Lewis, Duane Michals, and John Pfahl–Four artists in the exhibition Sight Reading: Photography and the Legible World discuss rewriting the rules of photography in Gilder Lehrman Hall

* 3 - 5 pm Live jazz music in Gilbert Court

* Ongoing Special docent tours all day

* Instagram photography contest

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

results.description:
As a group, we study a text--a story, poem, or essay, in English, Spanish or Latin--then each child, with your help, writes something inspired by the text. After that, the kids take turns reading their writings out loud while everybody listens in a sacred hush. The simple grace of this ritual changes lives. The kids we work with are the children of Spanish-speaking immigrants living in poverty.

We have welcomed many brilliant authors who provide the texts we study from their writings. To read their testimonials, please see: www.stillwatersinastorm.org/testimonials/. For a quick introduction to Still Waters, including video by CBS Evening News and press from The Huffington Post and The Guardian, please go to: www.stillwatersinastorm.org/about/. 


Feel free to bring a friend! 
Muchas gracias! 
Gratias maximas! 
Many thanks!

results.description:
As featured by ABC News and Time Out, The Amazing Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt is part hunt, part obstacle course & ALL FUN! 

You can come alone and be placed on one of our teams or you can sign up with friends. It is a great way to connect meet new friends or connect with old ones. 

A series of clues will lead your team around the Fort Greene/Park Slope area. You'll experience the excitement of being part of a team that solves clues & faces mental and (not-so) physical challenges in a race to the finish line.  

Each member of the winning group receives a gift package, and the pictures you'll snap along the way will be priceless.

GET TICKETS HERE:  https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

What to expect: 

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Knowledge about hidden parts of the city

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

*BUY TICKETS HERE ($25, price goes up as date gets closer) - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

*Prepay Only Event (No tickets sold at door) 

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for to walk. Dress comfortable – Most teams wear running shoes. 

What should I bring? A fun attitude, A Smart Phone if you have (either Android or I-Phone - fully charged) The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest. Please download that before you come to the event.

What if it rains? You won’t melt, we promise! The race still goes on. Races can actually be MORE fun in the rain! 

How many members will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. Based on pre-sales and RSVP's from other groups, we will have at least 25 people attending. 

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so get your tickets ASAP - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM
results.name: The Amazing Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt (Prepay Required)

results.description:
This week we are going to move and groove to the Angreji Beat at our Naach Xpress Class in JC. So bring your swagger ( and a hoodie if possible to add more swag) and lets have some fun!!

What is Naach Xpress? NAACH XPRESS is high-energy, fitness fueled dance class to Bollywood beats. It's one big dance PARTY! Students sweat it out to the best of Bollywood Funk NYC's signature dance moves. With a mix of jazz, hip hop, contemporary, and other well known dance techniques, we bring to you our fast track class to sweating it out with some style. Make some friends and dance the night away in this amazing class! There are no worries, come to class tension free and get your weekly dose of fitness and cardio! Each class will focus on ONE hot and popular Bollywood dance song. With a new song featured every week. ALL levels are welcome! Not a dancer? DON'T YOU WORRY! This class is for all, anyone can do it! 


Here is a class snip-it:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=70UcFvuNy1g

For further details and pricing for the class, please visit our website

www.bollywoodfunknyc.com

Looking forward to seeing you all there!!

results.description:
If you want to become a game designer and would love to know what it takes to make a living off your passion, then join us as we gain valuable insight into the game production cycle with Juan Maldonado. Juan Maldonado has 15 years of experience as a Game Designer, Project Manager and Producer for companies, Arkadium, Johnson & Johnson and his company GR2U. 


This event is part 2 of a 3 part series. 
Below is a breakdown of what will be covered at this event. 

-----------------------------------------------------------

Agenda

Pre-Production
- Hiring - Contract or Employee?
- Asset Creation/Acquisition/Repositories

Production (Project Management)
- SCRUM or Waterfall?
- Milestones
- Budgeting
- Communication

We are currently in the process of booking a place and time for this event. We will keep you posted.
results.name: Game Development Production Cycle - Stage 2 & 3: Pre-Production & Production

results.description:
Join us at our favorite meetup at Old Westbury Gardents - DOG DAYS! Roam the mansion grounds with your Cav and the group. Bring the family, water and treats. They have vendors this afternoon as well.

$12.00 General; $10.00 Seniors (over 62), $7.00 Children 7-17; 6 and under, Old Westbury Gardens members, and leashed dogs: Free.

http://oldwestburygardens.org/
results.name: DOG DAYS at Old Westbury Gardens LI, Sat. April 16th 12:00pm

results.description:
Rockefeller State Park Preserve is a state park in Sleepy Hollow, New York, in the eastern foothills of the Hudson River in Westchester County. Common activities in the park include horse-riding, running, jogging, birdwatching, walking, and fishing.

Let's meet on Saturday, April 16th and take a 1.1 mile walk around the Swan Lake. It's a nice, entry-level walk on a relatively level path that will even accommodate strollers. After that, there are more challenging paths we can choose and nearby attractions, depending on the weather and group.

Cancellation notice: I will cancel by 10:00 a.m. if the weather looks bad or if the hiking conditions are not great so please check your email before you head out. 


Meeting place: We will meet at the soda machines by the bathrooms in the parking lot and head out at Noon, so please arrive 15 minutes early.

More information on the park, how to get there and the hike itself can be found:

Here,

here,

...and here.

If you need or can share a ride, use the comments section below.   Metro north to Tarrytown plus a taxi can get you to the meeting place as well.

group.name: The New York Single Parents Meetup Group

results.description:
Building on the success of our December 5th workshop, we will present the latest iteration of Richard Carey's Game Design Canvas. You will construct the ENTIRE PLAN for a marketable, educational game, from product design to sales strategies. And you'll do it in less than 4 hours. Featuring the Game Design Canvas as a prototyping tool, we'll reverse engineer a popular game, then brainstorm our own, pick our favorites, and then team up to develop the game development plans. We'll end the afternoon by presenting our plans to the group and a panel of judges. This is an event not to miss, whether you're a returner or a first timer to our workshops.


Ticket price includes lunch. Sponsored by BrainPOP and Richard Carey Digital Media.
results.name: Game Design Canvas SUPER-Seminar, Design Workshop and Contest, #2!

results.description:
Photo Credit: Ron Richichi

LI-DOG cordially invites our canine families to our inaugural Pack Walk of 2016! 

Held on Saturday, April 16th at 12:00 p.m. (11:30 a.m. for registration) in the beautiful, English-themed splendor of Old Westbury Gardens, we will spend a delightful hour on a guided tour of the grounds with plenty of spring’s budding horticultural treasures for our eyes and our fur babies’ noses to take in as part of the Gardens’ Spring Dog Days Festival. 

RAFFLES!

Pack Walk Doggie Basket---Donate to LI-DOG’s cause to open local parks and beaches to our four-legged family members and get a chance to win our Pack Walk Doggie Basket of toys and treats for your pup!  Thank you, R&S Pet Supplies, Miller Place! For every $10 donation, four tickets will be given for the drawing at the end of our Pack Walk, approximately 1:45 p.m. at the registration table.  Winner must be present at the time of drawing to claim. 

Plus, just added: Raffle for Seresto Collar and Tick Removal Tool--just in time for peak flea and tick season! Generously donated by Bryn Elliott of Douglas Elliman Real Estate. The collar and tool will be mailed to the winner of a separate drawing of those who order an LI-DOG bandana personalized with their dog's name (normally $20, but only $10 at our Pack Walk registration table)!

PET PARENT ESSENTIALS FOR THE PACK WALK:  Please bring water and poop bags! 

OLD WESTBURY GARDENS DOG FESTIVAL/DOG DAYS:

Make sure to stick around after the Pack Walk and enjoy the Spring Dog Festival with booths and exhibits from local rescue and animal advocacy organizations like LI-DOG plus vendors of doggie goodies and gear. OWG's Spring Dog Festival runs from 11 a.m. until 4 pm. on Sat. only.

OWG's Spring Dog Festival is held in conjunction with Dog Days at Old Westbury Gardens when the grounds of this beautiful estate are open to on-leash dog walking. The grounds are open to on-leash dogs on both Sat. and Sun., April 16th and 17th from 10 a.m. until 5 p.m.

ADMISSION TO OLD WESTBURY GARDENS: 

***Our Pack Walk has no registration fee, but Old Westbury Gardens does charge admission in an effort to maintain their exquisite grounds***

Adult admission to OWG is $12

Seniors (age 62+), $10 

Children, age 7-17, $7

Children under 6 and canine children of all ages (on-leash), FREE!

DIRECTIONS: 

Please note when using your GPS, enter the full address 71 Old Westbury Road, Old Westbury, NY 11568.

We can’t wait to see you and your pooches on Saturday, April 16th!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the Blue Tent with LI-DOG on the front!
results.name: Inaugural LI-DOG Pack Walk of 2016 at Old Westbury Gardens!

results.description:
maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html

maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html

The financial district contains the oldest and, surprisingly, many of the most beautiful buildings and streets in the city, some dating back to the Dutch and Colonial eras. We'll step into the past by finding these historical gems nestled amid the faceless towers. As always, the focus of this walk will be more on seeing interesting and beautiful places than on listening to long stories about them, though I will provide the essential--and hopefully intriguing--information.

PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED. AND PLEASE DO NOT RSVP "NO" UNLESS YOU'RE CHANGING YOUR STATUS FROM A PREVIOUS "YES."

DISTANCE: About 3 miles. We'll finish at around 5 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

PACE: Moderate (about 3 blocks in 4 minutes), NOT SLOW.

LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll eat at around 2 or 2:30 PM.

COST: $2, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee.

TRANSPORTATION: No number 1, 4, or 5 service to Whitehall/South Ferry this weekend. Instead take the R to Whitehall/South Ferry or, a bit further, the J to Broad St., or, still further, the 2,3 to Wall St. Consult a street map that shows subway stops; tripplanner.mta.org; and/or maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html.

WAITING LIST: Be patient. There will be many cancellations, especially at the last minute.
results.name: Lower Manhattan: Splendors of the Past

results.description:
Acoustic Guitar for Beginners

101

Four 90-Minute Sessions

Held on 4 consecutive Saturdays.


FEBRUARY-MARCH - [APRIL 9, 16, 23, 30 -- 12:30pm]


WHO CAN ATTEND:
Beginning guitar students who have no prior knowledge of how to play guitar, or people who can play, but are unfamiliar with how to read and play from written notes.  NOTE:  Session #1 is MANDATORY for participation in the Series.


WHAT YOU WILL LEARN:
Learn to READ and PLAY NOTES, CHORDS and PLAY SONGS you know and love.  And what you learn is applicable to playing Rock, Blues, Folk, Country, Jazz, Classical or any other type of music the student is interested in playing.

MONTHLY, FOUR-WEEK CYCLES:
In this workshop, a specific set of concepts will be covered over a period of 4-week.  Each monthly, 4-week period will be closed to people who did not attend the 1st session of the month.  This allow the group to continue to progress through the lesson material and avoid the need to review all that came before each time a new person joins the group. There will be three to four monthly, 4-week cycles before the first cycle is repeated


WHAT TO BRING:
• Bring your own guitar for these lessons
• Also bring a three-ring binder and a pencil

COST:  The cost of this session is $15.00, which must be paid when you RSVP. 


IMPORTANT NOTE: If there are 5 or less people registered for this meetup, we will not meet at Ripley Grier Studios.  We will instead meet at the Sony Public Atrium, 550 Madison Avenue (Between 55th and 56th Street on Madison).  Watch for an email confirming where we will meet.
results.name: Acoustic Guitar for Beginners 101/C -- April (#1 of 4)

results.description:
Whether you’re new to fitness or have been working out for years, NYC In Your 20s is offering New Yorkers of all shapes, sizes and abilities FREE workout motivation every Saturday at 12:30 PM for six weeks, starting April 16, 2016.

NYC In Your 20s is helping New Yorkers get beach body ready by hosting their first annual fitness classes.  Over the course of six weeks, certified fitness trainer and nutritionist Oscar Flores and fitness instructor Bakari Taylor guide students through a warm-up before blasting through a series of fun, high-low impact choreographed workouts.  Suitable for people of all levels and free for everyone.  Sense of humor and flexible workout clothing required!
results.how_to_find_us: There will be 4 orange flags designating our area
results.name: Get Ready To Sweat

results.description:
As featured by ABC News and Time Out, The Amazing Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt is part hunt, part obstacle course & ALL FUN! 

You can come alone and be placed on one of our teams or you can sign up with friends. It is a great way to connect meet new friends or connect with old ones. 

A series of clues will lead your team around the Fort Greene/Park Slope area. You'll experience the excitement of being part of a team that solves clues & faces mental and (not-so) physical challenges in a race to the finish line.  

Each member of the winning group receives a gift package, and the pictures you'll snap along the way will be priceless.

GET TICKETS HERE:  https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

What to expect: 

• A fun day with with new friends 

• Knowledge about hidden parts of the city

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

*BUY TICKETS HERE ($25, price goes up as date gets closer) - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

*Prepay Only Event (No tickets sold at door) 

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for to walk. Dress comfortable – Most teams wear running shoes. 

What should I bring? A fun attitude, A Smart Phone if you have (either Android or I-Phone - fully charged) The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest. Please download that before you come to the event.

What if it rains? You won’t melt, we promise! The race still goes on. Races can actually be MORE fun in the rain! 

How many members will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. Based on pre-sales and RSVP's from other groups, we will have at least 25 people attending. 

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so get your tickets ASAP - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM
results.name: Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt (Prepay Only)

group.name: NYC Introverts That Want To Be Extroverts

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.


Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: C&B sets aside space for us from 12:30pm to 2:30pm so those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer if they wish.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at C&B, you will have to take a lesson from the range staff. If you are an experienced archer, you must at least stay for the safety portion (no exceptions, range rules). Lessons start at half past the hour so if you miss the 12:30pm, you may have to sit around and wait for the 1:30pm. Please be on time.

Public Transportation: LIRR to Hicksville and then a taxi from the station to C&B (make sure to tell them 11 Commercial St in Hicksville). The train from Penn gets into Hicksville at 11:55 am. The one-way cab rate as of 1/1/16 is roughly $6.30 (http://www.worldtaximeter.com/new-york/hicksville+train+station/440+jericho+turnpike%2C+hicksville) +$2 for each additional person. Those of you taking the train may wish to post a message to the group to share a cab.

Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rates:

$7.00 for the first hour, $5 each additional hour OR $15 to shoot all day
$1.00 for a target
$11 per hour for a rental bow and arrows
$5.00 for a lesson (includes first hour)

Visit the C&B website for the most up-to-date information.

See you on the shooting line!
results.name: Monthly Meetup at C&B Archery

• Knowledge about hidden parts of the city

• Mental and (not-so) physical challenges

• A memorable adventure with photos

• A story to tell

*BUY TICKETS HERE ($25, price goes up as date gets closer) - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

*Prepay Only Event (No tickets sold at door) 

Who can attend? All are welcome. This is not an age/ethnic/gender specific event. 

What should I wear? Dress for the elements. Be prepared for to walk. Dress comfortable – Most teams wear running shoes. 

What should I bring? A fun attitude, A Smart Phone if you have (either Android or I-Phone - fully charged) The hunt is run through an app called ScanQuest. Please download that before you come to the event.

What if it rains? You won’t melt, we promise! The race still goes on. Races can actually be MORE fun in the rain! 

How many members will be attending? This is a multi-Meetup group event. This page only shows a small portion of the actual attendees. Based on pre-sales and RSVP's from other groups, we will have at least 25 people attending. 

Where do I get a ticket? You must prepay to attend. Tickets will not be sold at the door. We expect this event to sell out so get your tickets ASAP - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/bkscavenger/dates/Apr-16-2016_at_1230PM

results.description:
As featured by ABC News and Time Out, The Amazing Brooklyn Scavenger Hunt is part hunt, part obstacle course & ALL FUN! 

You can come alone and be placed on one of our teams or you can sign up with friends. It is a great way to connect meet new friends or connect with old ones. 

A series of clues will lead your team around the Fort Greene/Park Slope area. You'll experience the excitement of being part of a team that solves clues & faces mental and (not-so) physical challenges in a race to the finish line.  

Each member of the winning group receives a gift package, and the pictures you'll snap along the way will be priceless.

Come brunch on great food and great drinks at Buttermilk Channel in Carroll Gardens!

Pecan Pie French Toast, Grilled Cheese, Buttermilk Biscuits, Cheddar Waffles - Say no more! Bellinis and Mimosas are offerings on the brunch menu, but the 4 Bloody Mary options come with lots of rave reviews!

Cash: Please bring cash! This restaurant does not split bills.

Also note: 20% gratuity is added to the bill for parties of 8 or more, and please show up if you RSVP! Xo

Public Transit:
The closest subway is the Smith/ 9th st stop on the F and G line. The F and G also stop at Carroll Street which is 5 blocks away and offers a lovely walk through the neighborhood. The B57 bus stops on the restautant block at Court between Nelson and Huntington.

results.description:
Come enjoy a bright [fingers crossed] Spring day outdoors hosted by our collective member, Lolita. 

We’re going to take a scenic walk through Central Park and take some pictures along the way. Winter is over, let’s get outside!

We’ll just be taking a leisurely walk through Central Park - talking, snapping pictures, and spending time outside of walls. 

All you need is a smartphone, no camera necessary! The main objective is to get outdoors, be active and enjoy the fresh air. If taking pictures  and photography are your thing, feel free to venture out and capture the scene(s) of your liking.


Details:

Date -  Saturday, April 16th // Rain date will be Sunday the 17th  

Time - 1pm meet time // we’ll be out and about for roughly 2 hours, 2.5 max 

Location - Central Park - meeting spot: USS Maine Monument - right inside of the park at Central Park West and Columbus Circle (on the map). It is a tower statue with a gold top and a fountain base (a picture) 

Transportation - [A, C] [B, D] or [1,2] B - to Columbus Circle

Feel free to bring friends and invite others

Afterwards, we’ll be stopping at a local venue to grab food/drinks and share some shots that we took throughout the day.

Please feel free to reach out to myself (Bri) or Lolita for any further details or if you have any questions.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
It is Drawing New York's great privilege to present a three-hour illustrated lecture on: Human Anatomy - Theory and Practice, by master sculptor and anatomist Frank Porcu. 

Mr. Porcu's dynamic, impassioned and intelligent lectures are legendary throughout the artistic community. This is a great chance to learn from a true master of the subject. 

In 2013, Mr. Porcu's sculpture, commissioned by The New York Historic Society, was unveiled by singer and fine artist Tony Bennet in New York City. Photos from the event can be seen here.

Frank Porcu’s philosophy and knowledge, grows from a 20 year hands on practice in stereoscopic medical dissection.  With a BFA from Pratt Institute, and an MFA from the New York Academy of Art Graduate School of Figurative art, he has 6 years additional training in traditional methods of stone carving.  Mr. Porcu has been lecturing on Anatomy, Drawing, Sculpture, and Painting to art and medical students for 20 years.  With students from the high-school up to the graduate level, his venues include: Pratt Institute, Columbia University, North Shore University Hospital Health System, NYAA Graduate School, the Art Students League, as well as numerous other small ateliers, and Universities throughout the United States.  Mr. Porcu practices what he preaches every day, as a professional commissioned sculptor.  Testing his theories and methods in his studio, he specializes in monumental figurative works and portraiture, in the late classical Hellenistic tradition.  He is also well known for his extraordinary skill and mastery of drawing and painting.
results.name: Frank Porcu Illustrated Lecture on Human Anatomy - Theory and Practice

results.description:
Join us for our April edition of GUY GALLERY WALK, where we check out 16 of the BEST art shows in the Chelsea Gallery District every month!

Here's our full itinerary of the walk:

1st STOP: PAUL KASMIN GALLERY [masked]th Ave @27th St) PRESENTS: ROBERT MOTHERWELL: THE ART OF COLLAGE

The exhibition is comprised of uniquely important works from the artist’s lifelong exploration of collage, showing the unprecedented diversity of approaches Motherwell employed in advancing the medium.


Collectively, the works in this exhibition have been included in dozens of institutional shows over the last half-century.  In White with Four Corners, 1964, first exhibited in 1965 at The Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C. and The Museum of Modern Art, New York, exemplifies the artist’s intuitive tearing methods – akin to the gestural movements of an Abstract Expressionist’s paintbrush. 

2nd STOP: GALLERY LELONG (528 W 26TH ST) PRESENTS: NARRATIVE/COLLABORATIVE; GROUP SHOW

presents photographic works generated through collaborative practices that emphasize and expand the aesthetic philosophy and range of the eight artists in the exhibition. These artists utilize photography as a medium for collaboration with another visual artist to develop specific projects. Through interaction, their work shifts focus and acquires new meaning. Narrative/Collaborative is a testament to the potential for establishing new creative ground when artists share their perceptions, technical skills and ideas to collectively create new work. 

3RD STOP: DRISCOLL BABCOCK (525 w 25TH ST) PRESENTS: LOST GENERATION, PAINTINGS

works done between[masked], selection of American works hallmarking the decade of the 1920’s when the United States and Europe were reeling in the aftermath of World War I. Gertrude Stein credited her auto mechanic with the “Lost Generation” moniker and Ernest Hemingway made it stick in The Sun Also Rises. While generally associated with writers, the “Lost Generation” was all encompassing—Americans who came of age during the First World War—some of whom served in the war, all of whom were subject to its upheaval.

4TH STOP: CLAMPART (531 W 25TH ST) PRESENTS: JAN RATTIA, TEASE

photographs by Venezuelan-born artist Jan Rattia. “Tease” is the artist’s first solo show in New York City.

Jan Rattia spent nearly two years traveling the Unites States—from Washington DC to Atlanta, Miami to Phoenix, and back to New York City—in order to photograph members of a singular and largely misunderstood fraternity: male strippers. Rattia’s images, however, go beyond what most people typically know of men in the profession. While sometimes shooting the dancers onstage as they present themselves to their audience, Rattia more often preferred to capture portraits backstage or at home, in order to create a more fully rounded picture of these men and their lives.

Rattia muses: “Backstage, preparing for their performances, the dancers primp and pump and shave to look their best and meet the expectations of their lucrative patrons.” However, he points out: “Each of the strippers has a story, in many cases mundane and generally unexpected. Most are straight, even though they clearly welcome the attention of other males. They may be students, businessmen, investors, and even doctors, or nothing more than what they appear.”

5TH STOP: THOMAS JAECKEL GALLERY (532 W 25TH ST) PRESENTS: ELIO RODRIGUEZ, PUZZLED

experiments with the construction of the intimacy of interior and exterior spaces, all things carnal and decorative, functional and artistic, manufactured and native.  His soft sculptures reimagine familiar forms using, in abundant measure, plant and carnal shapes, juxtaposed against sundry objects, metal screws, lace corsets, chains, belts, wire, filament, pins — with results that are pictorial equivalents of familiar concepts and concerns.

In his stuffed, massive soft sculptures, loaded messages about stereotypes, sexual or racial or otherwise, are hidden within exaggerated, provocative rendering of the mysteries of organic, invasive fauna, entangled in space by which a far-out untamed nature is introduced.  Lush, ritualistic, magical, multiple perspectives serve as metaphors for the state of his own Afro-Cuban-ism coalesced with the state of the female, as might be interpreted through the popular discourse in our modern times.

Elio’s work may veer into a kind of kitsch, but he does so magnificently in the most unlikely, playful, witty, voluptuous, sensory, sensual ways.

6TH STOP: MARY BOONE GALLERY (541 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: ROBERT BARRY, WORKS FROM[masked]

Robert Barry focuses on the site and the space between: between objects, between time, between places (metaphysical and real), between the artist and the viewer. Here, Barry utilizes words to realize a site-specific installation on the walls and the floor of the Gallery. In using language, the artist invites a sense of contemplation and encourages mental fluctuation; words announce an intangible and psychic exchange. The movement between states is best conveyed by Psychic Series (1969). Almost imperceptible, this gray vinyl text work is installed in the entry of the Gallery; it announces: “Everything in the unconscious perceived by the senses but not noted by the conscious mind during trips to Baltimore during the summer of 1967”.


7TH STOP: LUHRING AUGUSTINE GALLERY (531 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: JANET CARDIFF & GEORGE BURES MILLER, THE MARIONETTE MAKER

Cardiff and Miller’s kinetic installation The Marionette Maker (2014) comprises a full-scale vintage caravan that houses myriad characters in a haunting environment. The interior of the trailer reveals the fantastic world of a marionette maker (a marionette himself), who is hunched over a desk drafting designs. Viewers are able to walk around the camper and peer inside the puppets’ domain, as well as sit in theater seats adjacent to the trailer to watch the characters perform an opera. Recordings of forests and rainstorms emanate from rotating speakers above the trailer, overlapping with music made by the robotically controlled marionettes positioned throughout the installation. The audio elements continually intermingle, further enveloping the audience into the immersive, voyeuristic environment.


8TH STOP: MIKE WEISS GALLERY (520 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: MICHAEL BROWN, IN THE MEANTIME

thirty-three year old artist hand-cuts and polishes stainless steel until he has recreated a broken mirror. Brown embarked on the series in 2006 and began exhibiting the works internationally in 2007 with Yvon Lambert Gallery. The exhibition will feature eight works all in stainless steel with artist's frames and measuring 84 inches in height and 48 inches in width.

Brown begins abruptly, striking the surface of actual mirrors and surveying the cracks for appealing patterns to recreate.  Beyond this initial stage, however, the process is arduous and painstaking. For each work, Brown must cut and polish hundreds of pieces of stainless steel. Yet the imagery is still defined by immediacy – it conjures frustration and angst but also seems to capture an impulsive and gratifying moment of release, where deep-seated feelings surface and become tangible.

Throughout his career, Brown has maintained a conscious and highly meticulous focus on his materials.  “Stainless steel,” says the artist, “to me is a modern material that represents strength and efficiency….I like to think I’m embarrassing the material with my own labor.”  There’s nothing easy about Brown’s working method; he must exhaust hours on end of manual labor to achieve a result that adheres to his scrupulous standards.  Yet his result isn’t something that looks perfectly created; instead, the material appears broken – shattered to where the reflective purpose of the ‘mirror’ is moot. Looking into the heart of Brown’s spiderwebbed compositions, your vision becomes fragmented and it is impossible to see yourself clearly and in unity. 

9th STOP: CARA GALLERY (508 W 24TH ST) PRESENTS: AGOSTINO ARRIVABENE, HIEROGAMY

Investigating eternity, time, the process of change, the rites of transformation, and sacred love and death, Arrivabene utilizes symbols and images that are seemingly distant from the contemporary in order to create art that verges on the philosophical, sociological and even spiritual era.


Hierogamy recalls the Alchemic myth of the Hermaphrodite, namely the being that encapsulates all, an entity that encompasses everything. 

 brings together works created in varying pictorial techniques – oil on canvas or wood, cracked oil on brass, and painting on stone according to the ancient Wunderkammer tradition.


10TH STOP: YOSSI MILO GALLERY [masked]TH AVE) PRESENTS: JOHN CHIARA, WEST SIDE AT TIRIONDA

Instead of using film negatives, Chiara shoots directly onto color photographic paper with large-scale, hand-made cameras, the largest of which must be physically entered in order to position the photographic paper. While making an exposure, he burns, dodges and often filters the light entering through the lens as if working in the darkroom. Chiara processes these one-of-a-kind photographs in large sections of capped PVC pipes that he rolls across the studio floor. The prints retain traces of the developing process, such as streaks, drips, and unevenly saturated colors, evidence of the hands-on nature of making these pictures in an approach that is ultimately part photography and part event.


11TH STOP: ANNA ZORINA GALLERY (533 W 23RD ST) PRESENTS: ALEXANDER KALETSKI, OUT OF THE BLUE

12TH STOP: PAULA COOPER GALLERY (534 W 21ST) PRESENTS: CHARLES GAINES, NUMBERS AND TREES; CENTRAL PARK SERIES

Gaines creates work that often employs plotting and mathematics to organize visual components. While appearing systematic and scientific, Gaines’s works ultimately refrain from producing empirical knowledge, preferring instead to invoke the viewer’s subjective response. They explore an individual’s perception, expression and speculative thought, as they operate both within and against a system.

Charles Gaines’s new work, Numbers and Trees: Central Park Series I, marks an extension of his early interest in serialized projects. For each of his eight triptychs, Gaines divides and mounts a black and white photograph of a tree in Central Park, taken at the time of the artist’s 2014 exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem. Enclosing each panel within an acrylic box, screened with grids of half-inch squares, he graphs the silhouette of the tree directly onto the overlaid acrylic surface. Filling cells with vibrant paint, Gaines plots numbers to index the leaves and branches of each tree; he begins at the center of the trunk, counting outward in both directions to create a pixelated image guided by a numerical system. As the series progresses, the catalog of previous trees, each denoted by a different hue, appears on every subsequent triptych, resulting in a prismatic kaleidoscope of layered colors. The cumulative effect bridges the expressive sublime with the schematic referent.

13TH STOP:  DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (537 W 20TH ST) PRESENTS: STAN DOUGLAS, PHOTOGRAPHS

Held in conjunction with the United States premiere of the artist’s new film installation The Secret Agent, the exhibition on view at the gallery in New York will show significant series of works from the late 1980s to the present, includingTelevision Spots (1987), Malabar People (2011), among others.

The exhibition also marks the New York debut of Douglas’s most recent large-scale photographs, which further the artist’s ongoing investigations of photography’s complex and layered relationship to documentation, place, and history. In this series of dark, nearly indiscernible images, Douglas reimagines the postwar urban spaces of his native city of Vancouver, as it existed in 1948, when thousands of people exploited loopholes in British Columbia’s property laws to create provisional forms of accommodation in public spaces. Drawing on archival photographs and film footage, Douglas has digitally rendered several of these temporary urban structures and communities in minute detail. Inspired by film noir, he deploys subtle tonal shifts of black, gray, and white, cloaking the city’s interstitial spaces in shadow, while the eerily quiet scenes and dim pockets of light transform otherwise liminal structures and spaces into sophisticated theatrical mise-en-scènes. This historical reimagining challenges the conventions of the medium of photography itself, as the resulting hyperreal images are impossible photographs of a time and place unobserved by the camera, yet simultaneously fully dependent on the particularities of that time and place. As the artist has observed about these works, “It’s taking a photograph you can’t really take. The places aren’t there anymore and there’s no light.

14th STOP: JONATHAN LeVINE GALLERY (529 W 20TH ST) PRESENTS:  DAN WITZ; MOSH PITS, RAVES, AND ONE SMALL ORGY

Witz has evolved from being a pioneer of the street art movement to refining a studio practice that incorporates both digital and old master techniques. Influenced by the work of Renaissance painters Hieronymus Bosch and Pieter Bruegel, his large-scale oil paintings of rampant crowds embody a rebellious and provocative nature that’s heightened by a stunning hyperreal aesthetic.


and ERIK JONES: TWENTY SIXTEEN

Jones challenges viewers to see beauty in his chaotic, mixed-media works that merge nude subjects with nonrepresentational, abstract elements. Describing the human figures in his compositions as “aesthetic anchors,” they are the calming foreground upon which bursts of color, stenciled shapes and custom-made stickers create surreal landscapes. Using multiple mediums, such as watercolor, acrylic, colored pencils, wax pastels and oil paint, Jones’ portraits are technically complex and express a heightened sense of realism.


The relationship between Jones’ subjects and the abstract motifs that engulf them can be interpreted as conceptual fashion design. His portraits are dressed in a stunning hurricane of color and geometric patterns, 

15th STOP: DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (533 W 19TH ST) PRESENTS: THOMAS RUFF, PRESS ++

16TH STOP: DAVID ZWIRNER GALLERY (519 W 19TH ST) PRESENTS: STAN DOUGLAS, THE SECRET AGENT (FILM)

Douglas’s character by the same name is employed by the US Embassy in Portugal. He struggles to provide relevant intelligence and becomes entangled in an ill-fated plot to bomb the Marconi installation outside of Lisbon, an important telephone connection between the country and North America, and thus an umbilical cord between the Old and New Worlds.

Shooting on location in Lisbon with a cast including local actors, The Secret Agent revisits a decade also explored in Douglas’s series of photographs Disco Angola from 2012 and the film Luanda-Kinshasa from 2013. While these works addressed postcolonial liberation struggles and the African influence on the New York music scene, respectively, The Secret Agent invokes a broader narrative concerning changing notions of collective identity and the legacy of the modernist worldview.

The work is composed of twelve episodes that are paired by scene on six screens. Positioned in the center of the installation, the viewer becomes immersed in a given scene and must adopt the role of an editor to focus attention on any one part of the action. Characteristic of Douglas’s multilayered and nonlinear films, many of the scenes are shot from differing viewpoints and overlap chronologically. The overall narrative is divided into two sections, before and after a main event that is anticipated and dealt with, but never explicitly shown.

FEE: $5.00 payable to your tour guide Joey at the start of event

Explore your personal agreement between the heavens and the earth. In this workshop, you will journey deeper into yourself, nature, and the spirit world. Through prayer, offerings, healing, personal and shared reflection, you will gather in sacred space to connect with the spirits of plants and the natural world. You will journey with the spirit of a plant and become more aware of the energetics of your own body in relationship to that plant as you look at obstacles in your own healing. You will listen and explore the most appropriate ways that nature can bring you healing in honor of your personal agreements.

After April 9: $55 (WM); $60 (NM)

Goal: Get more familiar with JavaScript.

Whether you want to write your own programs in JavaScript or just want to communicate better with engineers, this class will get you started! This is part 2 of our 2 part free JavaScript workshop series, JS101 and JS201. Taking our JS101 workshop before attending JS201 is recommended, but you're more than welcome to come if you have very basic experience with JavaScript.

Prerequisites:

• JavaScript: Fundamentals: Syntax, Types, Variables, Keywords and Functions I

You'll leave knowing:

• JavaScript Fundamentals: Conditional Statements, Arrays, Loops and Functions II

Meet your instructor: 

Tyler Lambe was a professional developer across all platforms for over 6 years, before he made the transition into teaching full-stack web development. Having crafted full-fledged software engineers who previously had no experience, his passion lies in helping people accelerate their lives through education.
results.name: Learn to Code NYC Workshop: JavaScript 201

results.description: Eberron is a world where magic is technology, in which air ships, lightning rails, elemental galleons, and living constructs exist side by side with swords, armor, castles, and monsters. The Last War ended with the annihilation of an entire country by a mysterious magical cataclysm. While open war has ended, a shadow war among spies, nobles, dragonmarked houses, cults, and monsters has risen in its place. Join the adventure. Current players are level 4 and include a Warforged Fighter, Shifter Ranger, Tiefling Warlock, and Halfling Bard. results.description:
Long time Georgist, teacher, friend to many and Common Ground-NYC member Helene Breban passed away September 29, 2015 in New York City at the age of 90. Helene was born March 25, 1925 and was from a village in the Carpathian Mountains of central Europe. A holocaust survivor, she came to the US in 1952, having lost all connection with her family in Europe. She lived for some time in Pennsylvania, but mostly in New York City. Helene was a graduate student at CUNY in Sociology, and transferred out of that Graduate program to the New School. There she met the late Bruce Oatman of the Henry George School in New York City, and dedicated herself to teaching classes from 2004-2010. She was an active member of Common Ground-NYC, conveying her wisdom and wry humor along with underlying passion and compassion for humanity.

Venue, Date and Time:

John Haynes Holmes Community House, 28 E 35th St (between Madison and Park Avenues), first floor front room, on Saturday, April 16, 1:00 - 3:00 pm.
results.name: Helene Breban – Celebrating Our Colleague’s Life and Work

results.description:
REGISTER HERE

A free three-day intensive for photographers who find their flow pounding the pavement, camera in hand, eyes wide and searching for light. Photographers of all skill level and style welcome, street photography is not only a fantastic art form on its own, but a great way as a photographer creating within any genre to keep yourself fresh, stretching your creative muscles, practicing and getting to know your equipment so well you’re able to make work unobstructed. Participants are encouraged to join us for the full weekend, but more than welcome to come and go, joining any session they find interesting. 


Saturday, April 16th - Meet up at Union Sq Gandhi statue.

For the first 30-45min, we will stay in Union Sq, going over some basic shooting tips and tricks. Participants are encouraged to pair up with other photographers they haven’t met before and go through the exercises. Participants at this point have the option of either staying with the group as we wander down towards Chinatown, or pair off with other photographers and wander manhattan together, meeting up with the group later in the day, or on Sunday for the final piece of the workshop. (Shooting will more than likely run long for participants who would like to stick around).

*No matter what the weather is, Daniel Schaefer will still be hosting the walks - rain, shine, snow or sleet! Bad weather makes for great photos.


Daniel Schaefer is a photographer and writer based wherever his lens and pen are most useful. Currently making work in NYC he is known for his cinematically charged images ranging from delicately lit portraiture, to visceral shots of the lively NYC streets. His writings on photo theory have been met by much community acclaim, with industry standard sites like Petapixel, the Phoblographer, Japan Camera Hunter and Fstoppers publishing his articles. His work can be found at OutlierImagery.com or
results.name: Free 3-Day Intensive for Photographers - Workshop & Photo Walk - Part II
