This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

60min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson covering soccer techniques for passing, receiving, dribbling, turning, and much more. 

Please bring your own ball. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.


Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank

Past life regression is an amazingly therapeutic technique for accessing and re-experiencing ones past lives. By connecting with past lives, emotional and physical healing is experienced. Through Past Life Regression hypnosis, people uncover information such as discovering life's purpose, understanding relationships and a higher awareness of self. All of this leads one to a path of personal growth and healing.

Start your week experiencing the magical and healing experiences of past life regression hypnosis. With past life regression, you drift in to a dream like state in which you experience another life that may or may not seemingly have relation to your own life. It is through this experience that one releases emotional scars from this life and past lives. These emotional scars create imprints in the unconscious mind and are the roots to the blockages that we experience in our current life. Awareness is the key to healing. In this guided group past life regression workshop, discover how to unlock the doors to your past using a variety of techniques. You will connect with your higher self whereby you may release fears/phobias; heal wounds and emotions; uncover inner quests; understand your spiritual path or understand your life.

For more information, please visit SelfEmpoweredMinds.com

results.description:
S3 FPV Racing - Gates, Flags and Fun ! Public Event, CHYZOWYCH FIELD across the tracks from Columbia HIgh School.  Google Map to get a sense of where you are going.


NOTE : We are running time trials !! There will be some racing but the goal of the session is to record laptimes for submission onto MultiGP site.

If you do not have a Multi GP Pilot record yet, please create one and join our chapter : 


http://www.multigp.com/chapters/view/Safety-Third-Racing-Team

Race events will be posted to multiGP later.  Secure your spot by RSVP Yes to this meetup.

Arrival Time: 10:30 AM, Free fly begins 11AM


  Cost to fly:


• $5.00 Non S3 Members

• No cost to S3 Pro Members


Note: As there is no power onsite, you'll need to bring enough charged batteries to race the entire day or invest in field charging gear. Ask some S3 Team Members for equipment advice. This is an open field - bring at least a chair. More info below.

Check-in: When you arrive, please check in with the Event Captain (typically Frank or Will) for safety, frequency allocations and course updates. 

 
Agenda: 


· Sign in/Registration/Pre-Free-Fly/Frequency Assignments
· Free Fly Pilot Briefing
· Practice Heats
· Racing Pilot Briefing
· Live Heats / Racing (Various formats could include : Laps,Time Trials/Speed, Win and Out, Finals)
· Streamer Chase

 ________________________________________________
First Timers: If this is your first time joining us, Welcome! Please take a few moments and read the notes below on our best practices for piloting, frequency and safety management. PLEASE CHECK IN WITH THE FLIGHT/SAFETY COORDINATOR before you fly or power up anything. First timers will be paired with an established S3 Team Pilot as your “Event Buddy”. You can observe firsthand S3 team pilots doing the following: flight preparation, pit adjustments, frequency compliance, field behavior and group signaling/announcing. 


Got a non-racing, photography multirotor? It's always an awesome sight to see a large frame in the air capturing hi-res photography, so if you have one, please bring it. Please check in with Frank to make sure all video transmission is disabled. You will have to fly this line-of-site or run a 200mW VTX and adhere to frequency management to not interfere with the FPV racers.
Not flying? There's lot's of technical expertise, lurkers, newbies, and interested friends just hanging out, so even if you don't race, you can still fly, take videos, or just watch and learn. 

Please check in at the line of canopies at the end of the parking area and ask for Frank. 


  Suggested equipment to bring:
Your aircraft(s), props and batteries, repair equipment
Something to sit on – this is an open field.
Something to sit under like a small (or large) canopy. Team members do bring canopies to manage their equipment and make repairs. We ask that everyone respects the space they need to operate comfortably. 

AMA License: If you plan on flying, you can get it here: http://www.modelaircraft.org/). 

Safety glasses or high impact sunglasses (for young pilots under 13 it is HIGHLY recommended) 


Sunscreen and water. 

GENERAL HOUSEKEEPING:
NO FLY ZONE: For safety, the no fly zone is "IN, ABOVE AND BEHIND" the line formed by the pilot pit area. You may not operate your quad behind or to the right of the last canopy. When coming in for a landing, please approach slowly and don't prop wash/buzz everyone, there are lots of pilots "blind" with FPV goggles that can't tell if you are out of control or not. 


FLY ZONE: All pilots and spectators should stay out of the fly zone . Please pilot your aircraft from within the pit area (aka the no-fly-zone). If you crash or need to enter the field, please wait until races are over, and call out in the pit area your intentions so other pilots can avoid you. During free flight/ practice. you may enter the field by announcing “ON THE FIELD” loudly to entire pit area. 


CRASH & TRASH: Take out what you brought in, including a little extra while you're at it. That way we're always spotless and keep the park rangers happy. 

 
KIDS: we encourage bringing any family members and kids interested in RC flying, as it's a great place for young pilots to learn best practices in the art of FPV. For ground/flight safety purposes, we ask that all young pilots be always supervised and mentored on safe flying practices, kept away from dangerous fly zones, and be courteous/don't touch without asking in all staging areas. It is highly recommended for kids to wear protective eyewear. 

 
"ZERO HARM" RESPONSIBLE FLYING: Our group prides itself on minimal rules and attracts folks that are mindful, safety conscious oriented and considerate of other pilots, bystanders, pets, wildlife and the environment. IOW, if you are about to have a collision, especially with a dog, bird, human, or any living thing, think "zero harm" first and do everything you can to avoid the collision and immediately divert your flight path even if it means at the expense of your own rig. Living things are a lot harder to repair than metal and electronics and typically don't require litigation to fix. If in doubt please ask about best practices from any of the experienced pilots, we're all here to help learn and have a really great time together. 

 
RACING: Know your skill limits and pilot your quad accordingly. When flying, please be aware of other pilots calling out in the pit. Typically these are "Person on the course, dog on the course chasing rig, powering up on Vtx channel "X" , or the most critical, "VIDEO VIDEO!" and so on. It is critical you do not fly over people in the pit or other visitors in the park. But beyond this, most importantly, have a blast of fun! 

 
FREQUENCY MANAGEMENT
Since most pilots are using the 5.8ghz video transmitter bands for FPV video, so please be aware of your transmitter type (Fatshark/Immersion or Boscam) and frequency channel. Every pilot uses this technology to fly their aircraft safely, so it is imperative that every pilot understands and operates using safe video transmission practices. 

 
THE BASICS:
1) Never power up your video TRANSMITTER without first checking that there is no one else currently transmitting on the same channel. LOOK THROUGH YOU GOGGLES FIRST. Someone may accidentally be on the channel you were assigned. Listen intently when you do (even if you have a frequency tag), and if you hear a pilot exclaim that they've lost signal, power down immediately. Flying blind is a dangerous situation and is to be avoided at all costs.
2) Power up your video RECEIVER and goggles/display first BEFORE you power up your aircraft and video transmitter. If you see someone else's signal, then you need to switch your channel, you're stomping.
3) During races, only those in the race should be transmitting video .
4) For racing, the racing coordinator(s) will make frequency assignments and assign spotters.
5) Please arrange the video transmitter on your aircraft so that the dip switches/button to change your channels are easily accessible. You may need to change channels quickly just before your scheduled heat. 

 
Looking forward to seeing you there!

results.description:
This run will be beginner-friendly, but we welcome runners at all levels. We will be running anywhere from 2 - 6ish miles depending on what everyone is looking to do. 

The main starting point will be at Columbus Circle by the gold statue (not the silver unisphere).

Here are some options:

Advanced: 
6 miles: Lots of hills. Run along the full outer loop of the park. The hills are more challenging if you run counter-clockwise. 

Intermediate: 
~5 miles: Run along the outer loop but cut across the 102nd st traverse.  You'll skip the infamous Harlem hill.

Beginner: 
1.7 miles: Run around the lower loop. Cut across the 72st traverse and hang a left again once you hit the west side, end back at Columbus Circle.

If possible we will break into pace groups, but either way lets meet back at the USS Maine Monument around 12-12:15am.

Where do I leave my stuff? 
The New York Running Company at the Time Warner Center (located on the 2nd floor) has open bins, and lockers behind the cash register. To use the lockers, you must bring your own lock. They also have changing rooms. These services are free. The New York Running Company opens at 11am on Sunday. 

What time does the run actually start?
Plan on arriving at 11am, but we won't start running until about 11:15am in case people need to change or drop off their stuff at the NY Running Company. We will not wait longer that 11:15am.  

What happens after the run?
After the run once everyone is together again, we can grab some food! Weather permitting, we can get something to eat from Whole Foods (or wherever you like), and we can sit and eat in the park. We can walk over to the Sheep Meadow.
If the weather is not picnic-friendly, we can hit our goto place which is Cosmic Diner on 52nd and 8th ave. Hot chocolate, coffee, pancakes? Mmmm.. If anyone wants to suggest a different place that is close by, we're flexible.


Call/text Henry at (646)[masked] if you have any questions or are having trouble finding us.

Dig deep and drag yourself out to go for a run! You'll be glad you did!

** only RSVP 'No' if you were previously a 'Yes'.

results.description:
“Faith is taking the first step even when you don’t see the whole staircase.” -Martin Luther King, Jr.
Our April theme is faith: in what way are we, at the Society for Ethical Culture, people of faith? In the Ethical movement, we’ve said we have faith in the human capacity for ethical growth. In the 1876 founding address inspiring the first Ethical Society, Felix Adler said, “The time calls for action. Up, then, and let us do our part faithfully and well.” To what and to whom are we faithful?

Sometimes, “faith” means to believe in something, to be committed to something. In this vein, another Ethical Culture Leader, John Lovejoy Elliott, said, “I have known many good people who did not believe in God. But I have never known a human being who was good who did not believe in people.”

Interim Clergy Leader Jone Johnson Lewis will talk about her sense of the term “faith” from her perspective as a humanist — someone who believes in people.
results.name: Sunday Platform: A Humanist Explores Faith with Jone Johnson Lewis

results.description:
Thanks to those who came out for our first book club get together. Our next book will be "The Girl on the Train" by Paula Hawkins. If you loved "Gone Girl," you'll love this one! We'll be meeting at one of the members' apartments and everyone is encouraged to bring a snack and/or a favorite beverage (beer or wine a +)!!!! 

I'll be sharing the exact address as we get closer to the date. Let me know if you have any questions and happy reading!

A debut psychological thriller that will forever change the way you look at other people's lives.

Rachel takes the same commuter train every morning. Every day she rattles down the track, flashes past a stretch of cozy suburban homes, and stops at the signal that allows her to daily watch the same couple breakfasting on their deck. She’s even started to feel like she knows them. “Jess and Jason,” she calls them. Their life—as she sees it—is perfect. Not unlike the life she recently lost.

And then she sees something shocking. It’s only a minute until the train moves on, but it’s enough. Now everything’s changed. Unable to keep it to herself, Rachel offers what she knows to the police, and becomes inextricably entwined in what happens next, as well as in the lives of everyone involved. Has she done more harm than good?

A compulsively readable, emotionally immersive, Hitchcockian thriller that draws comparisons to Gone Girl, The Silent Wife, or Before I Go to Sleep, this is an electrifying debut embraced by readers across markets and categories.

results.description:
We will walk from Hartsdale to White Plains, have lunch at the Food Court at the Galleria and then walk back to Hartsdale.  It is about 5/6 miles, almost completely flat. 

The Bronx River Parkway Reservation, Westchester’s oldest park, is an 807-acre paved linear park that was created as an adjunct to the Bronx River Parkway opened in 1925.The reservation touts a number of “firsts” -- it was the first linear park in Westchester, as well as one of the first in the country, and, the Bronx River Parkway was the first parkway in the nation. It extends 13.2 miles in Westchester from the New York City line north to the Kensico Dam Plaza in Valhalla. The reservation also has the distinction of being the first official Westchester County park, whose establishment led to the creation of today’s county park system of more than 50 parks spanning nearly 18,000 acres.The picturesque reservation, which runs through the heart of southern Westchester County, features ponds, wooden footbridges and hundreds of varieties of native trees and shrubs. It is a favorite place for bicycling, walking, running and nature study.


 


Hike Rating: C


Leader: Andrea Minoff (203)[masked]
results.name: Take A Hike to the Bronx River Parkway Trail, Hartsdale, NY

results.description:
This platform will explore how we can learn to communicate with others in a way that provides real understanding, connection and empathy. The essence of our conversation will be to explore the qualities of communication where there is understanding, connection and empathy. We will uncover the hidden gift in conflict for it is indeed the opportunity to step into intimacy and speak what is truly in our heart.

If you are interested in learning more about Nonviolent Communication, please join us at our new practice group on April 14 and April 28. For more information, click here.

About the Speaker: Marty Epstein holds an M.S. in Negotiation and Conflict Resolution from Columbia University. He has been teaching negotiation at Columbia for the last five years and has taught conflict resolution at Pace University. Marty has been practicing Nonviolent Communication (NVC) since 2002 and is a graduate of BayNVC 2005 Leadership Program. Marty created and facilitated a workshop at Vassar College on Pedagogic Contemplation and Effective Conversation. He facilitated a core team in conflict resolution at Medgar Evers College and has given workshops at the United Nations, New Hope Community Center, The Center for Mind, Body, Medicine, The Center for Women’s Health, The Natural Gourmet Culinary School, and a major Investment Bank.


Marty has participated and taught at the New York Intensive for Nonviolent Communication for many years. Last year he facilitated the Integration Track of the NY Intensive. This workshop allowed participants the opportunity to address their questions regarding Nonviolent Communication and create a safe container to practice the skills learned in the classes. He will be offering the Integration Track again in the 2016 New York Intensive.

<a href="http://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rysec.org%2Fevent%2Feffective-conversation-platform%2F&t=Effective%20Conversation%3A%20Stepping%20Into%20Intimacy"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Visit www.rysec.org/directions
results.name: Effective Conversation: Stepping into Intimacy

results.description:
Everyone is invited to our platform meetings.

The Sunday School meets at the same time. The Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County helps children aged 2-14 explore and develop their moral and critical thinking skills through fun and interactive lessons and field trips. We meet weekly at 11am on Sundays for 1.5 hours while the adults of the Ethical Culture Society are attending the platform meeting. Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. The Sunday School Graduation Rite of Passage, completed by our 8th graders, allows them to present to the community how their Sunday School experience has informed their moral and ethical development.

results.description:
The NY state primary is upon us and the candidates have been wreaking havoc across the state - but particularly in our fair city, where the high concentration of voters makes it a particularly irresistible target for would-be presidential nominees.

We'll chat about our thoughts on the candidates, their trajectories, and what a good (or bad) showing in our state might mean for "momentum" going forward.

If anything else pressing comes up in the news (there hasn't been any large shift in the Belgian terrorism investigation, so I'm leaving the topic off for more time to discuss US politics) I'll add it to the list before Sunday.


**Note: We're returning to Cafe Grumpy this week but are capping attendance at 12 due to space issues. If you are not sure you'll be able to attend or have a change of plans during the week PLEASE change your RSVP. We have news lovers who might not be able to squeeze in this week, and we want everyone who wants to to be able to join!**

results.description:
Storytelling

This Improve with Improv workshop will focus on Storytellng. Storytelling is an invaluable skill for the actor. The actor not only portrays a character but they convey a writer’s story. In this workshop you will learn about story structure and how to effectively tell a story.

Through warm-ups, games and scene work you will have the opportunity to improvise stories that have a beginning, middle and end, and to tell the story with truthfulness, expression and character. You will also have the opportunity to create stories in collaboration and with others.


A fun safe and non-competitive environment is created in which each participant will learn how to work through inhibitions and tap into their imaginations.

Suggested Donation: $15* (or whatever you can pay)

*most improv classes in New York City cost between $35 -$50 per class session

The New York Primary is Tuesday April 19. I thought this would be a great time to look at the current election landscape and talk about how the current roster of candidates will affect both Feminism, Secularism and beyond.

Bernie Sanders has been winning young feminists.

Hillary has been struggling with the youth vote.

Donald Trump is a hot mess :)

Bring your thoughts, your hopes and your ideas. This will be a SAFE PLACE. All opinions welcome. Lets have a real conversation.

Here are some links to articles, videos, etc.

http://time.com/4220427/bernie-sanders-wellesley-hillary-clinton-femisim/


http://www.thenation.com/article/why-this-socialist-feminist-is-for-hillary/


https://youtu.be/UH9rC0MaBJc ( this video made me open up a little to Hillary after a long history of disliking her)


https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/book-party/wp/2015/08/05/donald-trump-on-women-sex-marriage-and-feminism/

If you have any other sources you would like to share send them to me and I will add to this list!

results.description:
Join Grand Central Atelier graduate Allison Parker for this one day Portrait Drawing Workshop

This session will cover the basics of the portrait drawing process with a mix of lecture, demo and exercises. Students should expect to learn basic portrait techniques while understanding continued work on their own will be required to gain proficiency. 

This session will cover:

1) Basic anatomy of the skull identifying bony landmarks and form giving muscles. 

2) A ‘block-in’ or detailed outline, using careful shading to suggest the unique forms of the portrait. 

3) The features which we will learn and apply as needed. 


Students will learn to trouble-shoot their work using visual comparisons, and measuring. Students are encouraged to work in graphite and white chalk on toned paper.

Instructors Work

Allison Parker completed a four-year course of study in classical drawing and painting at the Grand Central Academy. Her experience includes many hours of drawing and painting from the live model as well as ecorche´ and anatomical studies. Ms. Parker holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from the Savannah College of Art and Design in Painting and Illustration. Her work has received awards from the Salmagundi Club, the New York Society of Illustrators, and American Illustration Magazine. It has been featured on television as part of the documentary ‘Secrets of New York.’ Allison is a member of Brooklyn Brush Studios in Bushwick, Brooklyn where she paints and teaches privately.

results.description: Suffering from physical infirmities, ridiculed by his family, Claudius seemed an unlikely emperor by Roman standards but that's what he became upon the murder of Caligula. An accomplished historian, capable administrator and maybe crazy like a fox, Claudius rose to the occasion and accomplished much during his reign but unfortunately, was done in by those closest to him, his wives. Claudius' untimely (or well-timed) death, in turn made his adopted son Nero emperor. Nero's promising start soon took a dark turn, which marked his legacy. He is best remembered for his depravity, murder of his mother, tutor and countless others as well as his rebuilding of Rome following the great fire, which he is famously thought to have started or watched indifferently while pursuing his musical interests. We'll cover Rome during the life of this last Julio Claudian Emperor, RSVPs are closed, please indicate if you want a spot.
results.name: The End of the Julio-Claudian Line: Claudius and Nero

results.description:
Ever want to learn the art of Clay or know how to use but need a place to work? You found the right place.. We offer: hand building, slab work, coils, pinch pots, wheel work, painting and glazing.
Classes are on going. You can come with a project in mind, or get inspired the second you walk into our studio. You can make plates, mugs, vases, sculptural pieces, gifts, planters. We also offer painted pottery options for those of you who would like to paint only.
Wynne Noble the ceramic artist of Noble Plateware is teaching the class. Her handmade work which combines function, form & color to bring food to elevated heights. Meticulous care is taken so that each piece extends an unspoken invitation to look and look again. When paired with taste and touch, it delivers a true sensory experience.
http://nobleplateware.com/

Classes are $195 for FOUR classes. This includes all material, clay, glaze, paint, tools, etc.. and all firing costs. (You will need more than one class to complete a project.)

Classes are every Sunday afternoon 12-2PM or Tuesday evenings 7-9PM. Unless if there is a holiday. You can always text/call Wynne at[masked] for a fast response about class scheduling and cancelations.

results.description:
Third Sunday of the Month! So this week, we do show & tell - please bring in a short 5 minute presentation of your art.

A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.
results.name: The Artist's Way - SHOW & TELL week!

results.description:
Updated March 5, 2016

WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 

[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

Are you looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track, to be more FLEXIBLE and RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?


Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

$5 FOR FIRST CLASS TO CROSS TRAIN...

_________________________________________________

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by starting with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL enhance your alignment, performance, and overall sense of balance!


Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements on sheets of connective tissue can overtime shorten and tighten it in ingrained patterns around the muscles. This fascia restriction can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga For Runners class, one can experience tension release, fluid movement, and benefit from improved posture, circulation, injury prevention, as well as increased respiratory control and mental focus...

Each Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with a series of held Yin/floor postures. While surrendering into the edge of each pose (for 2-5 minutes), students are guided to experience the discomforting stagnant energy and its release around the hips, thighs, and lower back, and be connected to the present moment. The Yang flow sequence designed to follow will allow students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for greater circulation and achieve new level of flexibility and energy.  Guided Relaxation provided at the end will promise to be YUMMY!

__________________________________________________

Testimonies x3: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

"I ran my best time running a 18 mile course the day after..." Lori

“ I started taking Jennifer's Yin/Yang Yoga for Runner's Class over the summer, and it was fantastic. I had never practiced yoga regularly before, and was pleasantly surprised at how it helped to improve my flexibility, running, and overall fitness. Jennifer is a great, hands-on teacher, and really knows how the body works. I highly recommend this class! ” Theresa

________________________________________________________

THIS PERFORMANCE ENHANCING WEEKLY 1.25 HOUR CLASS IS NOT OFFERED ANYWHERE ELSE IN NYC! COME CHECK IT OUT!

By Cash or Check

Did I Already Mention----FIRST CLASS FOR ONLY $ 5!! 

This Meet Up RSVP $15

Class Card $130/10-Class Card, or $13/class *****BEST DEAL!

Bring a Friend Get a Free Future Class Pass!

Please dress in layers (cool to start) and it's okay to eat prior.  Please message any questions and pass this invite to your friends. Thank you and see ya you on the mat!


Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
This seems like a nice way to start off a Beautiful Sunday in Washington Square Park. 

The menu suggest that you can have an entrée' plus an alcoholic drink for $25.00 (tip included).  Most of the reviews say that the food is very good.  

We will Not have a jazz trio  playing........ but .......      This will give us a chance to "meet and greet"  with robust conversation and laughter.  ( which is sometimes difficult to do during a performance. 

After brunch we will go to the Park to "people watch"  and "socialize".  We will find out first hand how much things have changed since the good old days and ....... before they remodeled the venue. 

we will find a  "base camp spot"   and then get comfortable.  This Will be our "Meetup Base".   Everyone is free to come and go exploring the park and surrounding areas as they please.  At the home base we will be  socializing , and "people watching", and  stuff and things. 

The weatherman said that it was going to be a "lovely day" And I believe that it is true.

Feel free to go to the web site of "Washington Square Park",  and   "White Oak Tavern" .  You will find pretty pictures and a lot more details. 

Don't forget to visit  the group message board  (click on ''discussions").  There you might find information of interest to you.   This is also the place where you can communicate with the whole group .

[DIRECTIONS]: Grand Ave - Newtown [M, R] Walk down Broadway in the opposite direction of Queens Blvd. and make a right on Justice Ave.

We had a great turnout at the meetup last weekend! Let's keep the momentum going! :))

We are testing a new idea this week in which we will only be speaking in Mandarin. A lot of groups in New York have language exchange in which English and Mandarin are both being used but English ends-up becoming the predominant language of each group meeting. In-order for Mandarin learners to learn Mandarin they must be immersed in the language and this will give them the much needed immersion. 

The only RULE that we will have is that everyone must speak in Mandarin. Your level of Mandarin should be between intermediate and advanced but all are welcome as long as they speak in Mandarin. 

We understand some things that are complex must be explained in English but we do not encourage it.

*ALL ARE WELCOME BUT MUST MAKE CONVERSATION IN MANDARIN

*PLEASE DO NOT FEEL INTIMIDATED TO COME AND JOIN US

We should be done by 2:30pm but you all are welcome to stick around as long you'd like.

Thanks again for your support thus far and let's have many more great meetups! 非常感谢大家的支持！

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". THERE IS NO NEED TO POST WHY YOU CAN'T MAKE THE EVENT. 

BRING SUN PROTECTION, COMFORTABLE WALKING SHOES, LUNCH, WATER, AND AN EXTRA LAYER OF CLOTHING(THESE NEIGHBORHOODS ARE LOCATED UP ON HILLS OR RIDGES WITH BEAUTIFUL VIEWS, BUT IT MIGHT BE COOLER UP THERE.)

IF YOU CAN'T KEEP UP WITH A FIVE AND ONE HALF MILE, MODERATE PACED WALK WITH SOME UPS AND DOWNS, THEN THIS WALK IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU. WE'LL BE HAVING A LUNCH BREAK (AND REST) IN THE MIDDLE OF THE WALK.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will occasionally comment on some things (the architecture and social history of the Antebellum and Victorian private houses in these neighborhoods) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will, once in a while, stop at points of interest. These areas are surprisingly beautiful!

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John (the Event Host) who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. 

Description: We'll be walking through three neighborhoods that have Antebellum, Victorian, and modern private houses. In the 19th century/early 20th century, sea captains (including Captain Jacob Vanderbilt), ferry operators, shipping merchants (including Sir Edward Cunard), brew masters, local beer barons (including Bechtel and Hormann), and even the granddaughter of John Roebling (who designed the Brooklyn Bridge) built magnificent houses up on Staten Island's hills and ridges that have spectacular views of New York Harbor. Breezes and vistas made the hilltop a favorite of the wealthy who built estates there through the 19th century and early 20th century.

At about 2:00 PM, we'll stop for a lunch break in front of Silver Lake in Silver Lake Park, which has paved pathways. There also will be restrooms available. 


Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer’s Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time:  The meeting time is (before lunch) at 12:30 PM.

The Meeting Place: The meeting place is in front of the River Dock Café at the St. George Staten Island Ferry Terminal, Staten Island, NY. The River Dock Cafe is located at the western end of the mall at the St. George Staten Island Ferry Terminal. The address of the River Dock Café is One Richmond Terrace, Staten Island, NY.

After we meet, we will be walking (not taking the Staten Island Railway [SIR]) to these neighborhoods. At the end of the walk, we will be walking (not taking the Staten Island Railway) back to the ferry.

Before the walk, restrooms are located on the ferry or in the St. George Staten Island Ferry Terminal's waiting room, not far from the River Dock Cafe.

Below is in front of the River Dock Café located at the western end of the mall in the St. George Staten Island Terminal.

Public Transportation from Manhattan : Take any NYC subway train to lower Manhattan and then go to the Whitehall Staten Island Ferry Terminal at 4 South Street, New York, NY. TAKE THE 12:00 PM STATEN ISLAND FERRY FROM THE WHITEHALL FERRY TERMINAL IN LOWER MANHATTAN TO THE ST. GEORGE FERRY TERMINAL IN STATEN ISLAND, NY. THE FERRY RIDE TAKES ABOUT 28 MINUTES AND IS FREE. THE FERRY IS SCHEDULED EVERY HALF AN HOUR ON THE WEEKEND.

Below is the schedule for the Staten Island Ferry on the weekend.

http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/ferrybus/siferryschedule.shtml


Public Transportation from Staten Island: The Staten Island Railway (SIR) and many city buses go directly to the St. George Ferry Terminal (as most Staten Island residents already know).

Finishing Time/Place:  This circular walk finishes between 4:15 PM and 4:45 PM back at the St. George Staten Island Ferry. At that point, we'll likely take the scheduled 4:30 PM ferry back to lower Manhattan (Whitehall Staten Island Ferry Terminal). However, if we get back just after 4:30 PM, we'll then take the scheduled 5:00 PM ferry back to lower lower Manhattan. The ferry ride from St. George to lower Manhattan takes about 28 minutes and is free. The ferry is scheduled every half an hour on the weekend.

Rainy weather or other bad weather conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy weather or other bad weather conditions or the forecast is for rainy weather or other bad weather conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning (before 8:30 AM). This walk will only happen in good weather conditions. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.  

Below are some of the many beautiful houses that we will see in these neighborhoods. These houses were built from the 1830s to the 1920s.

Below is a view from one of the mansions that we were once lucky enough to be invited to go inside. 

Below is in front of that mansion.

Below is Silver Lake with dam. Silver Lake Park has many attractions including tennis courts, an 18-hole public golf course, a baseball field, and, of course, a lake.

Below was the tough job of ice harvesting at Silver Lake during the 19th century.(Photo Staten Island Advance)

results.description:
NY Trav Fest is coming to Brooklyn April 14 - 17! The 4th Annual New York Travel Festival brings together those who see travel as an integral part of their life, industry and media professionals, lifelong travelers, and those looking to figure out how they fit into the world of travel.

In Brooklyn for the first time, the main weekend of NY Trav Fest '16 will be at St. Francis College - 180 Remsen St, right around the corner from Borough Hall. Explore destinations from Iran to Cuba, panels, workshops, performances & more! Best part is that our group has INSIDE privileges (discounts on tickets and even our own space!! read on!)

The New York Travel Festival is a series of events for those whose lives are touched by travel: members of the travel industry, travel media, lifelong travelers, long-term travelers, college students, and people in career transition.

Their panels, speakers, and workshops provide professional development opportunities for those in the travel industry or wanting to join, as well as inspirational talks to offer ideas to an array of destinations and types of travel.

The festival opens on Thursday, April 14, at Rocco’s Tacos with an industry-only track presenting the latest tools for press relations and marketing strategies. On Friday, April 15, the festival’s 2nd Annual Travel Unity Summit (in partnership with Brooklyn Borough President Eric L. Adams) will focus on economic development through tourism at Brooklyn Borough Hall. The fun starts over the weekend of April 16-17, the festival moves to St. Francis College in Brooklyn Heights, with a two-day program encompassing expert panels and presentations on digital marketing, emerging markets, entrepreneurship, best uses of media, creating diversity, and sustainability in the tourism industry, and more, as well as performances, networking events and immersive exhibits from our partners in NYC and around the world!

You are welcome to attend any and all days, however if you would like to meet the rest of our group and access our private room, please join me on Sunday, April 17th at 3PM. Please make sure to click on the link below and then select the pass for you, at the bottom of the page you can enter the promo code.

Our promo codes are as follows:
ICALL - for $20 off All-Access Passes
ICWEEKEND - for $5 off Weekend Traveler Passes

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/new-york-travel-festival-2016-tickets-20154651104?aff=InternationalConnection&afu=131935832914

Without completing payment, your RSVP does not count. So please RSVP ONLY after making payment. Our private room is available to us only if we have enough people joining.  We will meet then and talk about what you thought of this event, plan trips, or talk about whatever is on your mind! Looking forward to seeing you there!
results.name: NY Travel Festival is coming to Brooklyn!

results.description:
Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: $24 Day­pass during the meetup. For monthly/yearly membership, the Initiation Fee (currently $99) is waived (no discount on monthly dues, for yearly membership please inquire with the Cliffs for discount). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is FREE for first-timers ONLY (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/ 
For Beginners, Climbing 101/Top-rope basic class is offered 50% Off. Must sign­up and pay in advance by calling the Cliffs at 718­729­76125.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:
Wild woman invites you to reclaim your body’s innate creative wisdom and return to nature. Relax, energize, balance; come home to your body through the chakras. Sink into your sacred ground, deepen your roots, reach up to the heavens and feel free to fly. Take a journey through the energy centers of the body with a unique blend of breath, meditation, stretching, toning, energy and sound healing.

Come away with simple tools you can use throughout your week to help you focus, relieve stress, and be present in your body.

This is a coed event <3

Suggested Donation $20 no one turned away for lack of funds.

**I'm donating all proceeds!! :)

I've decided to donate proceeds to help my family of heart. Here are the #2 love causes you'll help with by joining me.

#1 my friend Caro Saldivia's sister just got diagnosed with breast cancer, had surgery Thursday and is still recovering from a hysterectomy to remove a uterine tumor. She needs love and funds to help with medical costs and loss of work #2 Two families, the Mckinnons and the Montaya need our help.
My friend Lindsay and Tom Mckinnon lost their home and 2 boys to a fire. Their friends, the Montoyas were visiting with their two girls. They survived but Christy Montoya suffered severe burns and is still in the hospital.
They need our love and financial support

Let's send them our love and vision them, ourselves and our community whole.


You can also help the Mckinnons and Montoyas by posting this on your page
today "LOVING THE MONTOYAS AND MCKINNONS! www.youcaring.com/christymontoya and www.youcaring.com/mckinnon. PLEASE SHARE"


About Kiana
As founder of Be Wild Woman, Kiana is passionate about empowering women to reclaim and love their bodies. Her passion stems from her personal journey; recovery from trauma, healing from grief, sexual violence, painful cycles, cysts, depression, and shame. Kiana draws from her personal healing journey, studies of the feminine, sacred sexuality, energy healing, nutrition, chakra healing, ayurveda and creativity to empower women to feel at home in their bodies, safe, nurtured and loved.

She holds a B.S. in Behavioral Science from the University of Houston, and has certifications in somatic healing and holistic health. She is a Wild Woman Healer, Reiki Master, Integrated Energy Therapy Instructor, Vortex Healer, Holistic Health Counselor, Herbalist, Reflexologist, Interfaith Minister and Yoga Teacher

$30 in person/$33 via paypal - If you paid online PLEASE bring your receipt to class.

WFT Academy of Pagan Studies (WFTAPS) offers the most comprehensive, well-planned and affordable training available anywhere. We have a very interactive community based program. We provide many sources of learning that go into each and every class, which surpasses others when learning about Wicca / WitchCraft in New York City. We offer First through Third Degree training. Additionally we have many other Witch Crafting Classes & Workshops including: Herbal Intensive Series, Making A BOS, Tarot Classes, Besom Making, Candle SpellCrafting and much more.
What is wonderfully unique about WFT Academy of Pagan Studies is that it allows you to set the pace of your learning experience and provides you with an affordable way to grow within a structured Wiccan learning environment. You will be challenged and we do invite those who welcome this challenge to our Academy. We take your education very seriously, and in turn you should be serious about your education and training in the Path of Wicca / WitchCraft. Before considering enrollment and training at WFT Academy of Pagan Studies keep in mind that it is a life-path commitment.
Within our Academy there is an enormous amount of Community Interaction through the use of meetups, myspace, groups and now NEW! launching in 2013 online classes which will have our newly formed blog and forum etc., further enabling you to increase your knowledge and learning as well as providing you the ability to network with other like-minded individuals in a safe and supportive environment. Students can join this blog as long as they have registered at WFTAPS for classes
The Academy is truly a Spiritual Home and we welcome you to make it your own!
We have Degree-specific Study to discuss challenging lessons, facilitate rituals celebrating the Sabbats and Esbats as well as for healing and self-empowerment, all in a friendly and open atmosphere. We also hold Wiccan Degree dedications marking the stages of your training as you move through the Academy. We have found that many of our Students find it wonderful to be in a group learning environment that they can consider a Community Home.
We are all very proud of our Academy and what we have accomplished thus far. But ever mindful that it is each and every one of the Students that make it what it is. If you are reading this, we are confident that you would make a wonderful addition to our Academy and do hope that after reading this, you will decide to join us as at the Academy as a Student and member of The Wiccan Family Temple.
We welcome you to begin your studies by going to our ADMISSION AND PRICES (where you will find applications) page and submit your enrollment to the Academy today. We look forward to having you join us as a new Student of the WFT Academy of Pagan Studies.

WE ARE ALWAYS IMPROVING UPON WHAT WE OFFER STRIVING AND PROMISING TO ALWAYS KEEP RAISING THE BAR ON WHAT WE OFFER.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON CLASSES, EVENTS ETC. PLEASE VISIT US AT:
www.wftacademyofpaganstudies.webs.com
www.wiccanfamilytemple.org
www.thenycpagancouncil.webs.com
www.romanctichandfastings.webs.com
www.charmedbystarr.com for all your ritual and pagan items.

results.description:
It's back!!!

Come young Puggies, come old Puggies (and bring your humans too!), as it's time once again for the NNJPE's fabulously famous Easter Eggstravaganza!


We will once again be having our outdoor Easter Egg Hunt...eggs will be hidden in various *inconspicuous* locations among the delightfully grassy knolls of Best Friends! Inside each egg, will be a delectable Puggie treat; the more you find, the more goodies for your Pug...what fun! As if this wasn't enough; the one individual or team (team members must search together!) of whom finds the most eggs will win some eggciting goodies! We will also have one additional gift to be given away as a door prize, so the not-so-swift egg seeker need not fear, as you will have your own opportunity to *bring home the bacon*...I mean eggs (metaphorically speaking, of course...)!

To keep this event safe and sane for everyone, the dogs will need to be on leash for the duration of the egg hunt. If there is enough interest, we will then move over to the Ridgewood Dog Run for some off-leash playtime. (Originally, I had planned for us to utilize the Best Friends playroom, but unfortunately, that room will not be available for the next few weekends, so I have no choice but to move the off-leash segment of this event over to Ridgewood.)

PLEASE NOTE THE ARRIVAL TIME! You may begin to show up for this meetup at 1 PM (the egg hunt will start promptly at 1:20 PM and we will be setting up prior to 1, so please DO NOT BE LATE (or too early!), or you will miss the start of the event!

The cost of this event is $5.00 per human, and your exact change is greatly appreciated.

We are looking forward to seeing you, so hop to it and RSVP today!

Pugs 'n' Kisses to everyone!
Ellen
results.name: It's back!! Our 8th NNJPE Easter Eggstravaganza!

Okay. This one is an experiment in progress. Let's hold a book swap on Sunday, April 17 where we can exchange and/or donate some gently used books we no longer want and/or need.

HIGH DIVE
243 5th Ave
Brooklyn, NY 11215
b/t President St & Carroll St
Park Slope

1. You must bring a book in order to get a book.
2. How many books you bring? That is how many you can take.
3. Comic books will get you another comic book or a small book. Comic books (unless we're talking about a full sized graphic novel) do not get you regular hardcover/full sized paperback books.
4. You don't have to get a book after donating. You can simply donate the book or give it away.

For those who want to help me -- come to a final packing party at my house on Sunday April 17th starting at 1pm.  Please be aware that I have cats so those who are allergic may not want to attend. 

I will supply boxes, bubble wrap, tape, labels, markers, and beer, wine, water, soda.. and we will order some pizzas for all to enjoy at the end of the day.. 

I hope to be half way done by this date but will need help with final items.. not sure what will be left to do but I know I will need your help. 

There will also be plants and gardening containers for those to take and perhaps a big bookshelf, a nice wooden cabinet (hand made by my dad), and a wooden end table with 2 drawers, and other odds and ends for folks to take if they want..  Movers are coming soon after this last packing day so I need your help!! 


Thank you so much! 

Terry

results.description:
This is a co-ed adult pick-up game for all levels. 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe, Please bring  $4 in cash to the game. 

RSVP closes at 11:15AM (2 hours before the game)

PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP BY MIDNIGHT THE DAY BEFORE THE GAME!

No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP by midnight the day before the game will be red carded after the second offense which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.

Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Williamsburg Soccer Training activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Williamsburg Soccer Training Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Williamsburg Soccer Training programs or activities.

"'Who are you?' asked the Caterpillar. 'I hardly know, Sir. I know who I was, but I think I must have changed.'" - Alice in Wonderland


Let's get together! All are welcome. BYOB. Bring a dish if you want. Heather will make a big pot of soup and bake a cake! Just to chill, hang and meet/get to know each other better. 

If you want to share recent work feel free to bring the work or pics! I'll also have some art supplies out and about for messing around or collaborating. Feel free to bring your own!

Artists of all kinds are welcome - visual, performance, music, sound, graffiti, comedy, writers, etc... Feel free to share the invite! We will be making this a repeating event. 


*I am Heather, I have a big loft where I curate monthly art shows and let people come by anytime for free coworking. I just graduated from Baruch, Zicklin Business School with a major in Management : Entrepreneurship, minors in Information Technology, Social Responsibility, and Advanced Business Analysis. I'm building a web store for Brooklyn stuff, do promotional printing, am launching an app, and have a background in commercial real estate.

results.description:
this meetup will be repeating every two weeks like our veggie heaven bi weekly....
BUT, unlike our Veggie Heaven meetups, we need to have people who RSVP show up and be close to on time..........
If you need to call,[masked] 1066. please RSVP, unless you decide at the last moment to come, which is ok, if you call me. but if you decide at the last minute NOT to come, please be sure to call and tell me, so we don't reserve a table for 4 people who aren't coming, and get a chair thrown at us, or worse, a real cheese omelet.
please come on time, we will not be seated without all present, or we will be seated in increments as we show up, and will be dispersed. the management is willing to work with/accommodate us, but we need to meet them halfway, and as of late, we have not been consistent....  they want us all present before they reserve seats for us, they will not give us a table of 8 if only 4 are there in person.  they have reserved seating for 16 of us in the past only to have only 8 of us show up. they can't afford to keep seats empty waiting for no-shows during their busiest business hours. this has happened more than once. in regard to event time, the pancake house closes at 3pm, but sometimes lets customers linger. please do not count on this and show up at 3:45, it irks the management, and sometimes they do actually eject people at 3pm on the dot. please come as close to 1:30 as you can and communicate with me if you are having timeliness issues, decide at the last minute to come, or want to cancel, so we know what to expect for seating.....

as an aside, please consider;
The real reason why this event is called 'pancakes from hell'..... today(4/3/2016), we had a chair AND a REAL, really cheesy-cheese omelet thrown at us for taking up reserved chair/customer space, which lay fallow, costing the establishment moo-la. we need to be more consistent with our RSVP' status's and attendance times when it comes to our pancake events. otherwise there is hell for me to pay in my relations with this proprietor-(flames shot from his eye sockets). i am a regular at the pancake house, i live 5 blocks away, and to be a thorn in their side takes the fun out of an event, and makes patronizing their establishment on my own less pleasant for me. i don't deserve this. anyone's lack of compliance in my attendance guidelines screws up my relationship with this place of business, and i take this very personally.  please mind your RSVP's, i understand everyone here is human and might have issues, but please take my cell number and call to cancel if you choose to do so, close to, or after, attendance time. pick up the phone, it's the least you can do. please don't make me start counting indiscretions and banning people. :-(
thank you for your consideration.
results.how_to_find_us: please attend on time, or cancel if not coming. we will not be seated unless we all show. otherwise, increments of 4 or 6 will be seated, as we show up, separating us. many haven't been consistent with their RSVPs, resulting in a luke warm staff

results.description:
WE GOING TO WALK IN CENTRAL PARK. SOME IMPORTANT LOCATION IS MENTIONED HERE TO SEE AROUND THIS WALK; . 

We meet at 1:45 PM. We wait for everyone until 2:00 PM and then walk start.Please come early so you can meet and greet each other before start walk.

WE MIGHT SEE ALL BEAUTIFUL CHERRY BLOSSOM TREE IN SIDE THE GARDEN AND AROUND RESORVIR.

Conservatory Garden Center Fountain

With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot. From the steps of Vanderbilt Gate on Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the sweeping view of the Center Garden's formal green lawn is capped at the far end with this elegant geyser fountain. One of three stylized gardens that make up the six-acre Conservatory Garden, the Center Garden features hallmarks of its classic Italian design, geometric shaped vegetation, and fountains. The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

» Map It

Details

Hours: 8am to dusk

Wheelchair access at 106th St. gate inside Park

Restroom available

Quiet Zone (dogs must be leashed and kept on pathways at all times; no running, rollerblading, or bike riding; no organized, active recreation or sports allowed; headphones required for radios)


North Woods

Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

The North Woods is one of the Park's three woodlands (along with the Ramble and Hallett Nature Sanctuary), offering people and wildlife an oasis of nature in the middle of New York City. The heart of the North Woods is the Ravine. Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Location

East Side to Mid-Park from 101nd - 110nd Streets.


Blockhouse

Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is also the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice above the lower topography of Harlem. The rugged stone structure once had a sunken wooden roof and mobile cannon that could be deployed quickly. Today, the Blockhouse is empty, roofless, and securely locked.

Location

West Side at 109th Street and Central Park West.

Shakespeare Garden

Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

The garden was first conceived in the 1880s when park commissioner George Clausen asked the Park's entomologist to create a garden adjacent to the nature study center in the Swedish Cottage. In 1913, Commissioner Gaynor dedicated it officially to the works of Shakespeare. After years of neglect, Shakespeare Garden, just as most of Central Park, fell into disrepair. In 1987, Central Park Conservancy restored and expanded the garden, repaving pathways and installing rustic wooden benches and bronze plaques with quotations from the Bard's masterpiece.

Location

West Side between 79th and 80th Streets.

The Ramble

To use the words of Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted, The Ramble is a 38-acre "wild garden."  Central Park's designers imagined a tranquil spot where visitors could stroll, discover forest gardens rich with plantings, and meander along the paths. This truly is a place for the urban explorer to escape the city and get utterly lost in nature.

This was one of the first parts of the Park to be built, and except for the bedrock platform, it is totally artificial. Even the water running in the stream and the adjacent Lake is turned on and off like a faucet. Some of the trees you see date back to 1859 when the Ramble was planted.

Beneath the leafy canopy, you are surrounded by a thriving wildlife habitat. Because of its location on the Atlantic Flyway — the migration route birds follow in the spring and fall — the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species have been spotted, and over 40 other species remain in the Park all year long.

Every year, more than 25 million people visit Central Park, which is more than any other urban Park in the world. By working with environmental groups, the Central Park Conservancy has developed a woodland restoration and management plan, which involves your participation as well.

First, "carry in, carry out."  All of the trash and recycling bins have been removed from inside the Ramble, and placed at the entrances. If you enjoy a picnic in this beautiful setting, don't forget to take your leftovers with you and dispose of them properly. It's a simple gesture, but it really helps the environment and the Conservancy staff responsible for its care.

Location

Mid-Park from 73rd to 79th Streets.

» Map It

Belvedere Castle

Calvert Vaux, co-designer of Central Park, created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south. Belvedere provides the best and highest views of the Park and its cityscape. It's fitting, considering its name translates to "beautiful view" in Italian. 

"Right now, the temperature in Central Park is..." Since 1919, the National Weather Service has taken measurements onf New York's weather from the castle's tower with the aid of scientific instruments that measure wind speed and direction. In a fenced-in compound just south of the castle, other data such as the rainfall is recorded and sent to the weather service's forecast office at Brookhaven National Library on Long Island. After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

Location

Mid-Park at 79th Street

» Map It

Details

Open Hours:

10am-5pm daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day

Phone: [masked]

Bethesda Fountain

Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers. The fountain commemorates the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. The angel carries a lily in her left hand — a symbol of the water's purity, very important to a city that had previously suffered from a devastating cholera epidemic before the system was established. The piece is the only statue that was commissioned for the Park. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.


Mid-Park on the north side of 72nd Street

SUBWAY DIRECTION : 

TAKE # 6 TO 96 STREET AND WALK TOWARDS TO Madison Ave or Take M 86 bus from there. 


Bus: 

 M-1,M-2,M-3 and M-4 : Madison Ave bus to 96 street . Starbucks in corner.

The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Calvert Vaux, co-designer of Central Park, created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south. Belvedere provides the best and highest views of the Park and its cityscape. It's fitting, considering its name translates to "beautiful view" in Italian. 

"Right now, the temperature in Central Park is..." Since 1919, the National Weather Service has taken measurements onf New York's weather from the castle's tower with the aid of scientific instruments that measure wind speed and direction. In a fenced-in compound just south of the castle, other data such as the rainfall is recorded and sent to the weather service's forecast office at Brookhaven National Library on Long Island. After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

Location

Mid-Park at 79th Street

» Map It

Details

Open Hours:

10am-5pm daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day

Phone: [masked]

Bethesda Fountain

Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers. The fountain commemorates the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. The angel carries a lily in her left hand — a symbol of the water's purity, very important to a city that had previously suffered from a devastating cholera epidemic before the system was established. The piece is the only statue that was commissioned for the Park. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.


Mid-Park on the north side of 72nd Street

TAKE # 6 TO 96 STREET AND WALK TOWARDS TO Madison Ave or Take M 86 bus from there.
