results.description:
WE GOING TO WALK IN CENTRAL PARK. SOME IMPORTANT LOCATION IS MENTIONED HERE TO SEE AROUND  

We meet at 1:45 PM. We wait for everyone until 2:00 PM and then walk start.Please come early so you can meet and greet each other before start walk.

WE MIGHT SEE ALL BEAUTIFUL CHERRY BLOSSOM TREE IN SIDE THE GARDEN AND AROUND RESORVIR.

Conservatory Garden Center Fountain

With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot. From the steps of Vanderbilt Gate on Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the sweeping view of the Center Garden's formal green lawn is capped at the far end with this elegant geyser fountain. One of three stylized gardens that make up the six-acre Conservatory Garden, the Center Garden features hallmarks of its classic Italian design, geometric shaped vegetation, and fountains. The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

» Map It

Details

Hours: 8am to dusk

Wheelchair access at 106th St. gate inside Park

Restroom available

Quiet Zone (dogs must be leashed and kept on pathways at all times; no running, rollerblading, or bike riding; no organized, active recreation or sports allowed; headphones required for radios)


North Woods

Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

The North Woods is one of the Park's three woodlands (along with the Ramble and Hallett Nature Sanctuary), offering people and wildlife an oasis of nature in the middle of New York City. The heart of the North Woods is the Ravine. Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Location

East Side to Mid-Park from 101nd - 110nd Streets.


Blockhouse

Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is also the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice above the lower topography of Harlem. The rugged stone structure once had a sunken wooden roof and mobile cannon that could be deployed quickly. Today, the Blockhouse is empty, roofless, and securely locked.

Location

West Side at 109th Street and Central Park West.

Shakespeare Garden

Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

The garden was first conceived in the 1880s when park commissioner George Clausen asked the Park's entomologist to create a garden adjacent to the nature study center in the Swedish Cottage. In 1913, Commissioner Gaynor dedicated it officially to the works of Shakespeare. After years of neglect, Shakespeare Garden, just as most of Central Park, fell into disrepair. In 1987, Central Park Conservancy restored and expanded the garden, repaving pathways and installing rustic wooden benches and bronze plaques with quotations from the Bard's masterpiece.

Location

West Side between 79th and 80th Streets.

The Ramble

To use the words of Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted, The Ramble is a 38-acre "wild garden."  Central Park's designers imagined a tranquil spot where visitors could stroll, discover forest gardens rich with plantings, and meander along the paths. This truly is a place for the urban explorer to escape the city and get utterly lost in nature.

This was one of the first parts of the Park to be built, and except for the bedrock platform, it is totally artificial. Even the water running in the stream and the adjacent Lake is turned on and off like a faucet. Some of the trees you see date back to 1859 when the Ramble was planted.

Beneath the leafy canopy, you are surrounded by a thriving wildlife habitat. Because of its location on the Atlantic Flyway — the migration route birds follow in the spring and fall — the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species have been spotted, and over 40 other species remain in the Park all year long.

Every year, more than 25 million people visit Central Park, which is more than any other urban Park in the world. By working with environmental groups, the Central Park Conservancy has developed a woodland restoration and management plan, which involves your participation as well.

First, "carry in, carry out."  All of the trash and recycling bins have been removed from inside the Ramble, and placed at the entrances. If you enjoy a picnic in this beautiful setting, don't forget to take your leftovers with you and dispose of them properly. It's a simple gesture, but it really helps the environment and the Conservancy staff responsible for its care.

Location

Mid-Park from 73rd to 79th Streets.

» Map It

After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

The Stilt-Sands are destroyed, and a terrible leviathan has awoken to plague the Ten Isles once more. All that remains of hundreds of sails and thousands of sailors are two ships and three hundred souls. Precipice Port is a fortnight away, the only destination for hundreds of miles of ocean, and you must reach it. Not all is as it seems amongst the sailors and refugees, however. Someone or something has slipped aboard, and its intentions are surely murderous. Can you reveal the hidden evil before it is too late?

Fortnight of Fear is the fourth chapter for the WildPig Exclusive Campaign "Sailing Against the Wind" by Noah Anderson. New and returning players are welcome. Characters are 7th level, with a limit of 8 players per session. There will be time for character creation a half-hour before the first session. Seats are limited, so please register ahead of time.

results.description:
Click the link below to purchase a ticket to this event:


http://www.bigmaven.com/experience/behind-the-scenes-the-paley-center-for-media/

Join New York Adventure Club for a behind-the-scenes tour of the Paley Center for Media, an organization founded by CBS President William S. Paley that leads the discussion about the cultural, creative, and social significance of television, radio, and emerging platforms for the professional community and media-interested public.

Our all access experience throughout the 16-story Paley Center for Media NYC headquarters, designed by American architect Philip Johnson, will include visits to the:

• Chairman’s Suite, filled with the original furniture and objects from founder William S. Paley’s CBS office.

• The Kissinger Room, often used by the Paley Media Council, an exclusive membership community for media industry leaders

• Control Room, a working studio and video archive that produces the public programs for the Paley Center collection

• Grant Tinker Boardroom, filled with original pieces by world-renown caricaturist Al Hirschfeld

• Bennack Theater, where casts and creators of such programs as 30 Rock and Mad Men have entertained and informed audiences.

• The Edward and Patricia McLaughlin Library, where the Paley Center's permanent media collection of over 160,000 television and radio programs and advertisements can be accessed.

As a special treat, we'll finish with a look at some of Paley Center's exclusive television footage, including the original broadcast of the Apollo 11 Moon Landing!

Afterwards, we'll grab some food and drinks in the neighborhood!
results.name: NY Adventure Club: Behind-the-Scenes @ the Paley Center for Media

results.description:
We've been talking about reading a Hugh Howey book, and I thought we should go with his first big one:

"This is the story of mankind clawing for survival, of mankind on the edge. The world outside has grown unkind, the view of it limited, talk of it forbidden. But there are always those who hope, who dream. These are the dangerous people, the residents who infect others with their optimism. Their punishment is simple. They are given the very thing they profess to want: They are allowed outside. "

BoingBoing's Official Review:
"This story is terrific. I was completely immersed, watching Howey slowly paint a picture of a society gone wrong through the eyes and discovery of some truly compelling characters."

Ernie Cline, NYT bestselling author of READY PLAYER ONE -- "With WOOL Hugh Howey has created a new science fiction classic! The riveting storyline and detailed prose sucks you in immediately and makes you feel like you're right there in the silo with his characters. But unlike them, you'll be in no hurry to leave."


LOCATION
We will be meeting at the Citigroup Atrium.

There is an entrance at 53rd and Lexington Avenue off of the 53rd and Lex subway stop. You have to go down the steps; the subway station will be on your right and the Atrium will be straight in front of you. The doors are labelled.   

There is a Barnes and Noble (with a Starbucks inside) located on the next level up at 54th and 3rd. If you enter through the B&N, you will need to go through B&N (up a few steps from the entrance), past the NOOK display to the glass doors and down the escalator to the Atrium.

There is free wi-fi in the Citigroup Atrium. There are also free public restrooms. Please let me know if you have any questions about the location.

It's probably more fun if you read/finish the book.  But if you don’t, you are still welcome to come. But there will be spoilers!

WHERE TO BUY
The book is available in hardcover and digital, including Kindle at Amazon.  There doesn't appear to be a Nook version but here's the book link to Barnes & Noble.


IMPORTANT RSVP POLICY
If you RSVP and find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP so that we are not waiting for you. Please change it no less than two hours before the scheduled meeting time. If you RSVP and do not show, you will have to pay $10 when you attend your next event. This is to prevent those on the waiting list from missing out on an event.   

The RSVP policy is the same as for the general meetup. Please see the entire policy here:  http://www.meetup.com/NYSciFi-Fantasy/pages/Membership_Policy/

results.description:
Disclosure Network New York

Date: Sunday, April 17, 2016

Location: CAP 21 Studios, 18 West 18th St., (Between 5th Ave. & 6th Ave., South Side of Street), elevator to the 5th Floor, Room 505, NYC

Time: 2pm-4pm,Please be on time, as late arrivals may disrupt the meeting. Enter the room assigned at 2pm. Ask the Welcome Desk person for “Nick Curto's room assignment” if you need help in finding the room. Please be on time, as late arrivals may disrupt the meeting. Enter the room assigned at 2pm.

Topic: “Buried Under the Intersection of Reality & Myth: The Atlantic Avenue Tunnel, the World's Oldest Subway”

Featured Guest Speaker: ROBERT DIMOND

Program (Live Event): Unknown to most New Yorkers, the world's first subway is under Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue in Cobble Hill. The tunnel, built in 1844 by the Long Island Rail Road, was sealed up in 1861 and its reality was completely forgotten. The "Atlantic Avenue Tunnel" was reported in contemporary newspapers to have been the location of several violent deaths, and a venue for poltergeist activity, shadow people, "river pirates", smugglers and thieves, bootleggers, a Presidential Assassin (John Wilkes Booth)- as well as a circa 1836 wood burning steam locomotive.

Although no one could find a way inside, or even prove it really still existed, the tunnel's mystique attracted a variety of researchers, ranging from a certain CIA Director of Counter Intelligence, to a then 19 year old college student who in 1980, actually got inside, and rediscovered the tunnel and its amazing history. Bob Diamond will be regaling us with his presentation on the past, present and future of this unique historical resource, which has captured the imagination and prose of writers ranging from Walt Whitman to H.P. Lovecraft.

Bio: A life long Brooklynite, from a very early age, Bob Diamond has always had a duel passion for science and history. When he was a high school senior, Bob won a science contest for alternative energy sources. The reward was meeting some fascinating people. Later, Bob used these contacts to provide logistical support for his rediscovery of the Atlantic Avenue Tunnel. Bob has been the President of the non profit Brooklyn Historic Railway Assn. since 1982, and has recently created seven books of modern rail transit technology.

http://tracks.lionel.com/abandoned-and-buried-the-worlds-first-subway-tunnel-and-the-trapped-locomotive/

Please plan to attend what is bound to be one of the most interesting DNNY meetings to date and invite your interested friends to join us.

Meeting Details: Admission $10 per person. Children 12 and under admitted free. Our treasurer will collect your admission fee in the meeting room door before the program begins.


R.S.V.P. now to guarantee you one (1) reserved seat! (30 seat venue room limit.) Provide your full name, e-mail address and cell phone number.

We mostly play newer "euro" style board games (Agricola, Tzolkin, etc.) that often run 1.5 to 3.0 hours. In addition, many take a long time to teach (Alchemists runs about 30 minutes, Kanban's teach ran 1 hour last time).  Among the shortest games we play are Codenames and Splendor.  If you arrive while games are going on, prepare to hang out and chat while they finish up then organize for a new game. We are permitted to bring food into the lobby, but EVERYONE MUST BUY AT LEAST 1 THING FROM THE BAR, AND TIP THE BARTENDER VERY WELL. The venue we are using is a business and we want them to be glad to have us there.

Please keep noise level down to a minimum to avoid distracting the hotel guests and clean up after yourselves (the trash area is just a few feet away).

"Jitterbug Perfume" is an epic. which is to say, it begins in the forests of ancient Bohemia and doesn't conclude until nine o'clock tonight [Paris time]. It is a saga, as well. A saga must have a hero, and the hero of this one is a janitor with a missing bottle. The bottle is blue, very, very old, and embossed with the image of a goat-horned god. If the liquid in the bottle is actually is the secret essence of the universe, as some folks seem to think, it had better be discovered soon because it is leaking and there is only a drop or two left.

results.description:
Please join us for Lichens in Central Park with lichenologist Jessica Allen on Sunday, April 17 at 2 PM. Lichens are organisms formed by fungi and algae living together in a mutually beneficial relationship. They grow all over the world, from the arctic tundra to the tropical rainforest. While they are tolerant of extreme habitats, they are notoriously sensitive to air pollution. During this walk, we will explore the common species of lichens that can withstand urban air pollution and are found in New York City parks. We will discuss the role of lichens in ecosystems and the evolution of these unique symbioses.

Please meet at 110th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd (on the park side) at 1:50 PM as the tour will start promptly at 2 PM. If you have difficulty finding us, please call, (917)[masked] or (917)[masked]. Free event. No reservations necessary. All are welcome.

Jessica Allen is a Ph.D. candidate at The New York Botanical Garden and the City University of New York Graduate Center. Her research focuses on lichen conservation in eastern North America, and especially on rare species with narrow ranges. Though her research is now focused on eastern North America, she has studied lichens all over North America, from Alaska to Georgia. Allen is originally from Washington state, and she studied biology at Eastern Washington University before moving to New York City. She also served as vice president for the The Metropolitan Society of Natural Historians.

NB: Our photographer will be taking photos of this event for our website. If you attend this event and do not wish to have your photo posted to our website, PLEASE let us know the day of the event.

In the event of heavy rain, this event will be canceled.

We hope to see you there!

The Officers of the MSNH
results.name: Lichens in Central Park with Lichenologist Jessica Allen

group.name: The Metropolitan Society of Natural Historians

results.description:
REGISTER HERE


A free three-day intensive for photographers who find their flow pounding the pavement, camera in hand, eyes wide and searching for light. Photographers of all skill level and style welcome, street photography is not only a fantastic art form on its own, but a great way as a photographer creating within any genre to keep yourself fresh, stretching your creative muscles, practicing and getting to know your equipment so well you’re able to make work unobstructed. Participants are encouraged to join us for the full weekend, but more than welcome to come and go, joining any session they find interesting. 


Sunday, April 17th - Editing & Critique at Adorama 


Our first hour will be spent discussing editing techniques that suit street work especially well using Adobe Lightroom, including some of my own custom presets that will be available for download.
Participants are encouraged to bring their laptops and edit their images either prior to, or throughout the course of the class.  Participants will then choose their three favorite shots from the weekend, and we’ll critique the results as a group. The first 100 participants will leave with an AdoramaPix voucher redeemable for an 8*10 metal print.

Some notes for attendees:

1. Join the Alumni facebook group: http://bit.ly/1nOAsW8


2. Email 2-4 finalized JPGs of shots you would like to add to the critique pool. Files named with your full name. Send to [masked].


3. Laptops are encouraged for Sunday's session, but not necessary. 

Daniel Schaefer is a photographer and writer based wherever his lens and pen are most useful. Currently making work in NYC he is known for his cinematically charged images ranging from delicately lit portraiture, to visceral shots of the lively NYC streets. His writings on photo theory have been met by much community acclaim, with industry standard sites like Petapixel, the Phoblographer, Japan Camera Hunter and Fstoppers publishing his articles. His work can be found at OutlierImagery.com.
results.name: 3-Day Intensive for Photographers Part III - Editing & Critique at Adorama

results.description:
Meri, who is an excellent astrologer, will lead this meeting on the Behenian fixed stars. Please contact Meri at [masked] with your date of birth, time and city, so Meri can create your astrology chart, showing the Behenian Fixed Stars - if you have any in your chart.

The Behenian fixed stars are a selection of fifteen stars considered especially useful for magical applications in the medieval astrology of Europe and the Arab world. Their name derives from Arabic bahman, "root," as each was considered a source of astrological power for one or more planets. Each is also connected with a gemstone and plant that would be used in rituals meant to draw the star's influence (e.g., into a talisman). When a planet was within six degrees of an associated star, this influence was thought to be particularly strong.

Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa discussed them in his Three Books of Occult Philosophy (Book II, chapters 47 & 52) as the Behenii (singular Behenius), describing their magical workings and kabbalistic symbols. He attributed these to Hermes Trismegistus, as was common with occult traditions in the Middle Ages. Their true origin remains unknown.

You are welcome to bring healthy snacks to share.
A $3.00 donation is asked to pay the fee for our meetup page.

Looking forward to seeing you all!
results.name: The Behenian Fixed Stars

This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 3-5pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking?

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers?

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life.

This class is free!  There is a suggested donation of $10 or whatever amount you feel like.  The donations would go to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.

Hope to see you there!


Steve

Meet on field 8!!!

Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated 

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.
results.name: Sunday Pick-up Parade Grounds 3:30 PM

results.description:
NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED SOCCER GAMES @ Frederick Douglass Playground


                                 Check our Facebook page:

              facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer 

                          NO CLEATS OR PLASTIC STUDS ALLOWED

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41MNlrZf-MY

GAME DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

Game Format:

We'll play three simultaneous games of 7 on 7, with small goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 9:00 am on Sunday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

1-First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!

2-Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

3-No power shots allowed.

4-If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

5-If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.


6-Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location:

Frederick Douglass Playground


Take the 1,2 or 3 RED Line Train to 96th street Station and walk 4 blocks down, to 101st Street and Amsterdam Ave. or the 1 RED Line Train to 103rd Street Station and walk 1 block.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S. 

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes(No CLEATS), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to Royale for brunch and a Pint or Two:

                                       Lion’s Head Tavern 

                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
RSVP's begin Thursday night April 14th at 7:00pm.  If you have been on a prior East Village Tour please give others a chance!  We have a lot of newer members!  TOUR IS FREE WITH SUGGESTED DONATION OF $1 or $2.

The Streit's Matzo factory opened on the Lower East Side in 1925 and closed its doors in January of this year.  We hear the wrecking ball is coming next week - ironically just before the Passover Holidays.  http://ny.curbed.com/2016/4/11/11410660/new-film-chronicles-streits-matzo-factorys-history-ahead-of-its-demolition

Join me on a walking tour in which we'll stop by the factory and visit the Art on A Gallery which is having an exhibit celebrating the release of"Streit's Matzo and The American Dream - A Film By Michael Levine", which will be showing at the Film Forum  4/14/2016 - 5/5/2016.

But first -- we'll stroll through one of my favorite neighborhoods the East Village (which for most of its history was  part of the Lower East Side), taking a look at the community gardens, along with some attention to immigrant history and the creative arts and squatters movements.

After the tour we'll end on or near East Houston Street, convenient to subways and an optional visit to a local beer hall which also serves food and wine.

Cheers from Hank

[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: N or R train to 8th Street or #6 to Astor Place.  Rest rooms at Public Theatre lobby, also the K-Mart and Starbucks on Astor Place.
results.name: Farewell to Streit's Matzo & Earth Day Tour/East Village & Lower East Side

results.description:
The Autumn 2015 special edition of Jewish Currents magazine detailed more than 50 acts of Jewish armed resistance during the Holocaust. Now translated into a traveling exhibit, the premier installation of "Resistance is the Lesson" will be on view at the Puffin Cultural Forum from April 17 to May 4. The opening will feature Lawrence Bush, Editor of Jewish Currents magazine and Anna Wrobel, a daughter of survivors and a historian of the Holocaust. Together they will present an exploration of the reality of Jewish resistance, and the origins and impact of the “sheep-to-slaughter” myth.

Free Event

New Rules: RoundRobin 3 teams of 4 players. Teams rotate every 10 minutes. Please bring a white shirt, a dark shirt(black,navy,dark grey) and a bright colored shirt(red,blue,yellow,orange,pink,green)

We'll have a dark team, white team and the colors team

Arrive on time 5:45pm!!! Late comers will wait on the sidelines to be placed in the game.

We start at 6:00pm.

4v4 small goals

Rules:

Fun Play
No Sliding
Goals after half point only.
kick-ins.. no throw ins.
Kick-off at midpoint after each goal.

To promote generosity, honor and respect, PS2G plays clean soccer!! This means No Cursing, Insulting, Complaining, Arguing or Fighting! We welcome you if this is your usual style and you want to change your attitude to fit our culture
All proceeds go to our charity network: http://ps2g.org/charities

Bring indoor shoes or sneakers, Dark,colors and white shirt

Please be sure you are definitely showing up when RSVPing.
Refunds are only given when PS2G cancels a game. If PS2G cancels a game, please go to this link ps2g.org/games/refund-request for a refund.

There is a minimum of 4v4 with 8 RSVPs needed to have a game. Game will be cancelled if this number is not reached 1 hour before the game time. Check comments for updates from Game Leader.

If you can't afford the meetup fees, please visit our website to learn how to become a game leader. Game Leaders play for free. http://ps2g.org/gameleaders

results.description:
Dear Yogis & Yoginis:


Greetings! ^_^

Welcome to my FREE beginner yoga class coming up this Sunday. Cannot wait to see you all. ^^ The class this week is open to yoga lovers, in particular, beginners. It emphasizes the fundamentals of yoga through informative instructions. As intermediate to advanced yogis may find it too simple, it is always good to go back to basics to refine our alignments of asanas (steady and easeful yoga postures). The class will also include meditation to help us relax and relieve all the stress we have carried through the whole week. With that being said, you are all warmly welcomed! :)

The studio is located on the 9th Avenue and in between W 50th Street & W 51st Street in NYC. Please press the button "Sonic Yoga" and the secretary will buzz you in. After you enter the building, head directly to the 3rd Floor, where the studio is located.

Please kindly bring a yoga mat with you. If you do not have one, you can rent it for $2 at the studio. Props are free of charge. Restrooms and shower rooms are available for use. 


Important Notes: 


1) Please be on time for sign-in and the setting up of your mats and props. Warming up is essential in avoiding injuries in doing yoga so you don't want to miss that. ;)

2) Please take off your shoes before you enter the room on the 3rd floor.

2) Please put your phone in silent or airplane mode if you decide to take it with you into the studio.

3) Please return all the props and mats properly to the conditions they were in upon leaving. Your cooperation is much appreciated!

See you this Sunday!

Love and light.

Namaste, 

Shuai

results.description:
Rock Climbing! Top of our popular events! Join our amazing group of men and women of color as we defy gravity, cheer each other on and have a great time!.

We're all hooked. Fitness, fun and conquering fears what's not to love. 

Belay Class & Cert is an option, don't let it stop you from coming out on any date. They have Automatic Belays so don't so sweat it.

So excited about this we've got some great group rates! We do this once a month.

Note: We have a strict 4 No-Shows without word and your out of the community policy, so update your RSVP @ least 3 hours before if plans change so we can better accommodate folks (Don't Say I Ain't told you).


Price: $24 What! (Includes shoes & harness) Interested in Cliffs Membership see BPLOA Special Group Rates.

Beginners welcome! - We are not doing a beginner class but there are staff in the beginners area that can show us the ropes before we start.

Dinner/ BBQ will follow a few blocks away! (Ohh That Corn Bread Tho). 

Bring a small padlock for the locker if you have one!

Transportation: 

Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Pics of Newbies & Intermediate climbers from previous events: * Rock Climbing 11/29 

*Rock Climbing Intro 1/10 Photos.

Beginner Rock Climbing Videos. So you don't look brand new :-)

results.description:
Futsal Pick up games (intermediate to advanced level)

Fee: $10 dollars per player per game; pay through paypal.

Only 10 players per game, no subs. One game is 55-60 minutes. Be early. Every player rotates as a Goalie for 6 minutes, timed it with an electronic scoreboard. We play without a break. Regulation size goals with nets. Futsal ball. Please make sure to bring a white and a red t-shirt, indoor shoes. Games are competitive, but friendly. Please keep in mind that these games are definitely not for the beginners. 

Please no fouls, zero tolerance to this. “Futsal is not a physical but a technical game ”. Minimum physical contact means fewer injuries and no violence. No charging, no displacing with your arms or body to gain the position on the ball. No running into the opponent. Play the ball, not the player. Time it, don’t foul it. 

Refunds will be honored only with a minimum of 24 hour cancelation.  No refunds for late cancelations; no exceptions. 

The school entrance is located on East 109th street between 2nd and 3rd avenues (near 2nd avenue) on the south side of the street. You'll see a row of 5-6 metal doors. Open the door or ring the buzzer (on your right) and someone will open the door for you.

For questions,  use the MEETUP message and notifications tools. 

Post pictures and videos at:

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Futsalacrossamerica?ref=hl

Twitter: https://twitter.com/FutsalAcrossA

Thank you for being part of Futsal Across America.

Enjoy the game!

Please join us to see perhaps the most famous duo in traditional Irish music today, Martin Hayes and Dennis Cahill, as they return to New York to play the Highline Ballroom on this night.

Founding members of The Gloaming, Hayes is a master fiddler from Clare. Cahill, born to Irish parents in Chicago, accompanies him on guitar. The two have been playing together for nearly 30 years. You can read more about them when you buy your tickets HERE.  

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XkxtRbQ_0ZE

And about those tickets. Enter discount code CELTIC25 to get 15% off the regular price of general admission tickets. So $25 instead of $29.50. We'll have a reserved table, you can indicate when you sign up whether you'd like to sit with the group or not. $10 food and beverage minimum at the table. The concert starts at 8, meet starting at 7.

results.description:
We've rescheduled this to Sunday, 4/17 to accommodate out-of-town visitor Tyler Alterman. Tyler is the president of EA Global and director of growth and strategy at the Centre for Effective Altruism. Will MacAskill may also be visiting. 

For newcomers, read on:

If you aren't already familiar with the wider EA movement, I'm glad to have reached your eyeballs! Effective altruism is about recognizing the importance of using our lives to do the most good we can and looking for ways to help others that are high-impact and well-supported by evidence. This approach may sound obvious, but careful consideration of the impact of different strategies for doing good can lead to some surprising, and even controversial, conclusions. Ethical philosophy, career strategies, economics, and persuasion methods play important roles in these considerations, so EA attracts smart people and provides intellectually invigorating topics of discussion.

A great way to start learning about our perspective is to watch Peter Singer's TED talk: 
http://www.ted.com/talks/peter_singer_the_why_and_how_of_effective_altruism?language=en

If it piques your interest, have a look through the introductory links on the Effective Altruism Forum, or read Will MacAskill's excellent book on the topic, Doing Good Better -- and let us know what you think!

Feel free to send me a message if you'd like to know more. Hope to see you there!

-Chris
results.name: Effective Altruism Meetup

Come and receive - spiritual nourishment and an opportunity to relax and rejuvenate - in the physical and every other sense. We've had some amazing gatherings Sunday after Sunday - sunshine for the soul through each and every one's Light - their presence and spiritual participation. This is what make Neolyth such a well of positive atmosphere - community gatherings of kindred spirits. We are 'spiritual beings having a human experience' and every one has unique gifts to offer from and through their Soul.

These gatherings will now provide a space to lie down in Savasana or relaxation pose while listening to live sound of alchemical crystal bowls, guided imagery, and spiritually oriented ancient verse and poetry. The door will remain open for you to come in quietly and find a comfortable mat and seat. Small donations appreciated!
results.name: Sunday Night Meditation with Crystal Bowls

results.description: We meet every Sunday night from 7:30-8:45 pm at South Mountain Yoga. We do a 20 minute guided meditation (usually one of Thich Nhat Hanh's), walking meditation, and a 20 minute silent sitting. Jean also picks a reading. At the end, there is time for sharing (optional) as a way to practicing listening and speaking about issues of mindfulness in our week, sittings, and daily lives. No experience is necessary.  There is a suggested donation of $10. Please try to arrive on time and refrain from wearing fragrances.  Cushions and folding chairs are available or you can bring your own. Please note: many sangha members attend the group without responding here on meetup.
results.how_to_find_us: Next to the Chase Bank; next to the sound garden. One flight walk up to 2nd Floor. Parking on street or in parking lot behing the buiding. No meters on Sunday.
results.name: Sunday Night Meditation

results.description:
New Swing Dance Session With Spencer @ The JCC in Manhattan

334 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY @76th street

 with  Spencer Weisbond

Six week, progressive session : Mar 13, 2016-Apr 17, 2016
Sun
7:30PM - 8:30PM & 8:30PM - 9:30PM
# of Sessions: 6
Except:  Feb 7th No class!
  102: Advanced Beginner -  7:30 -8:30pm Advance in Jitterbug and East Coast Swing by learning more involved patterns with harder footwork. Build your dance vocabulary and partnering skills. This class is the prerequisite for Lindy Hop (level 3), which is the grandfather of all swing dances and has 8-count patterns. No partner needed


  103: Lindy Hop﻿ Pre-Intermediate 8:30- 9:30pm
Bring all your moves together into complete sequences. Learn new eight-count patterns to make your dance more intricate and expressive.  

  Teacher: Spencer Weisbond please call me with questions about your level[masked]
Level one is now on Wednesday nights!
  Register and pricing below:

  Level 102: http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=643452733&_ga=1.167298430.1141896589.1397581416

Level 103: http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=643452749&_ga=1.201402577.1141896589.1397581416 </a>

Spencer has been dancing swing since 1998. He has studied Lindy hop extensively with 4 time world champion and 8 time American champion, Nathalie Gomes. Spencer had led the outreach program for Hop Swing And & Jump dance studios at local venues around NYC.
Spencer has had his own program in swing at the JCC in Manhattan for over 8 years, and also teaches privately. He has taught for Lincoln Center’s “Midsummer Night Swing” He currently organizes the New York City Swing Dance Meetup Group, which has over 3400 members, making it one of the most active swing dance clubs in the world. Spencer also co-founded the popular NYC dance  event “Swing Remix”. <a href="http://www.SwingRemix.com">www.SwingRemix.com </a> <a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=135393">

<a href="http://ebiz.jccmanhattan.org/personifyebusiness/Programs/ProgramDetail.aspx?pid=135408"></a>

results.description:
I want to thank everyone who came out for this, What a great show and an amazing meetup. we had so many people we couldnt accomodate all but its was a great show and i hope everyone met each other. Were gonna continue doing this as long as the club lets us. I met some of the most fun and amazing people, the comics were a full top Comedy Central line up too. For those of you who havent been to this, This is a special Meetup, we finally got a deal with Stand Up New York the hottest club in New York City to let us in free of charge and see comics like Amy Shumer, Godfrey, Kevin Brennan and top names, this is NOT an amateur show like alot of the meetups. I just ask that everyone who Rsvp's really do their best to show up AND MAKE IT ON TIME. as you know I dont charge for this meetup so come out see the hottest comedy show and maybe even make some new friends. this sundays line up includes the below.

Host Goumba Johnny brings you: Ari Shaffir!!, Sam Morril (Comedy Central), Damien Lemon (Guy Code), Chloe Hilliard (Last Comic), and Phil Hanley (Tonight Show). and pretty much any comic you see on Comedy Central these days drops by and shows up on the lineup who knows who might drop by usually its Amy Shumer or Judah Friedlander.

I will be at the front end of the bar by the iphone charger as usual to meet with everyone and give you tickets for free admission and have everyone sit together so we can all share laughs. Try to be early the show starts at 8 and everyone sits at same table but i do this earlier so all of you can meet your fellow meetup members. This is a 2 show ticket, so if you show up for the 8 you can stay for the ten also which has a different but also comedy central lineup. Or if you would like to come for the 10 you can just say meetup at the door and they will point you to me.
results.name: Comedy Central Meetup at Stand Up New York Free admission 2 drnk Ari Shaffir

results.description:
** Due to crazy technical errors we are going to be doing this webinar again.  Thank you for your patience **

To set everyone up for the Foreclosure Real Estate Summit on April 30th I have decided to do a webinar focused on the basics of foreclosure investing. 

For those who do not know, Foreclosures is one of the most popular type of real estate opportunities to buy.  Why?  Its because when people are behind on their mortgage payments they become what is called a motivated seller.  When people are motivated to sell, houses go for dirt cheap.  Typically 50 to 60 cents to the dollar.  :)  Want to learn more? 

Join us for the webinar and learn: 
1. What is a Motivated Seller? 
2. The foreclosure timeline & when on the timeline is best to go after deals? 
3. Equity Deals, Short Sales 
4. Sheriff Sales & REOS 

To your continue success, 

Nick Tang 
P.S. We may only be able to cover 3 of the above topics. So please let me know which of the 3 you want to hear about in the comment section of the site.  The one with the most votes will be discussed.  Thank you 

Log-in Details:  
Webinar log-in details well be emailed to you before 5pm on the day of the event. The webinar will start at 8:00pm.  Please Log-in early. 

Recording:  
This webinar will be recorded.  It will be made available for a month to everyone that has already bought tickets for the Foreclosure Summit coming up on April 30th.
results.name: Webinar: Foreclosure Real Estate Investing Basics

results.description:
Ok folks, it's the third Sunday of the month, again- the day you all get to have a great time being being horrible people with a rousing game of Cards Against Humanity. Because so many of you enjoy it, we decided it was best to give you monthly recurring opportunities to be horrible. I'm sure we're doing a great service providing a safe outlet for these urges.

We'll be playing at The Uncommons, a tabletop gaming cafe. If by any chance Cards Against Humanity isn't your thing, they literally have a menu of dozens of games for you to enjoy, along with more typical menus for things like food and drink. For the small fee of $5 plus tax, all of these things will be available to you for the entire evening (The games, not the food and drink).

So come out and enjoy the guilty pleasure of being acceptably horrible with a card game, or play another game and sit in quiet judgment of the rest of us (both options have their appeal). Either way, join us for some fun games and good company this weekend.
results.name: Cards Against Humanity

results.description:
Hey, let’s start the group back up with a show from Brooklyn’s own Roy Nathanson at Littlefield on Sunday, April 17th! Roy formed the Jazz Passengers with longtime cohort Curtis Fowlkes a few decades back, and has worked with everyone from Elvis Costello to Deborah Harry. This will be the album release show for his "Nearness and You” LP, and he’ll be playing with Curtis Fowlkes, as well as the very talented Arturo O’Farrill, Marc Ribot, and Anthony Coleman.


From the Littlefield site:
A one-night reprise of Nathanson's residency at the Stone in June 2015 - a night of improvisation including a variety of interpretations of "Nearness of You" and original compositions in duo and as a full band.

Tickets are $12.00. You can order them at: http://www.littlefieldnyc.com/event/1044437-nearness-you-ft-roy-brooklyn/

YouTube some of "Nearness and You” at: https://youtu.be/Ovd0qsvdXOc

Let’s revive this Brooklyn meetup with some serious Brooklyn jazz….
results.name: Catch Roy Nathanson at Littlefield (April 17th, 2016)

results.description:
We've planned this now as a weekly meetup, so that everyone in the group can get together even if the moderator can't be there.

If Darren can't make it to introduce everyone (he can't this week), could someone please take it upon themselves to 1) stake out the big table a little early, 2) Lead a go-around-the-horn o? introductions at 8pm, and 3) Time the 60 minutes of writing time and let everyone know when it's 9 pm.

As always,

Please RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change. We have had far too many no-shows.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.

Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

7-8 pm - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
8:00 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on
8:05 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
9:05- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like. Feel free to keep writing if you've got the momentum going! Be aware Argo closes at 10pm.
If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. It may just be "pipe-cleaning" for now, but you'll feel better showing up at the page. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: Argo Tea Cafe, Columbus Circle Subway Station. 1792 Broadway.

SOME TIPS:

Argo has plenty of outlets - we will be on the back, large table.
Seats are hard to come by, and I can only save so many, so please, come on time! If you come late, we might have already started.
The music and occasionally nonmember conversation can be loud, so bring headphones too.
WiFi is available with purchase.
It's a little chilly, so if you get cold bring a sweater.
And it goes without saying that buying a cup of joe or a snack from Argo for being nice enough to host us will bring you good writing karma.
If you aren't sure you can make it, please don't RSVP! Come on time or even a little early, as it can be difficult to save seats.
results.name: NYC Shut Up & Write Meetup! - Columbus Circle

Hope you are all well and enjoying the Fall.

I am offering an Energy Transmission on Sunday Nights at 10PM, especially for weight loss!

Good nutrition is the core, for good health and successful weight loss, and good energy nutrition is important as well.

This will help you to relax, recharge, replenish, and will help you with stress eating, cravings, and to keep focused, and to feel better about your body and yourself.

A special and delicious vitamin essence, will fill you up with good nutrition, which will help you fill up with the good stuff, therefore you will feel more satisfied with less food, and helps you to absorb the nutrients your body needs.

This will also relax and strengthen your adrenal glands, and help to revitalize all of your glands and organs.

I really hope you enjoy this gift, and if you have any questions  concerns, please let me know.

I will have this each and every Sunday at 10PM! And, in the comfort of your own home.

All you need to do is relax, and intend to receive the Weight Loss Energy Transmission from Jae.

It's that easy, and then you can just relax and enjoy! Do not worry about falling asleep, because the energies work great while you're sleeping. They will work even if you are distracted or if you forget.

All you need to do is to RSVP so that you are on the list.

Please RSVP for each week that want to be included so that I know you're in.

Hope you'll participate in the next Weight Loss Challenge in October!

I'd love to see you!

Hope to see you real soon!

 

All the very best,

Jae

results.description:
People ask me how I can speak seven languages all the time.

It's simple...

Study hard consistently, challenge yourself and use the language daily. That's how you'll get fluent in your target language. I study languages every day from six in the morning. Can you keep up? It'll make you fluent!


Join me at Starbucks whenever you'd like to study hard, practise conversation, and share good energy.

English? Español? Français? Italiano? 中文? 日本語? 한국어?

Whatever you're learning, good, daily study habits will make you fluent. 

Try it out!
results.name: Let's Get Fluent! Language Study at Starbucks

results.description:
*** If you haven't joined our Facebook group yet, make sure you do! That's where a lot of the action happens: links to our photo albums, extra workouts, happy hours, random funny meme postings, you name it!

facebook.com/groups/therisenyc

----------------------------------------------

This one workout will keep you amped up all week long. Seriously, give it a try and you will be hooked!


The exercises may change from week to week, but it is always a Tabata-style interval workout: 20 seconds of high intensity work followed by 10 seconds of rest. Then repeat! Exercises include sprints, burpees, squats, situps, box jumps, step ups, pushups, dips, and other “no-frills” exercises.


Warm up beforehand by running, biking, or walking. We start promptly at 6:30 AM and the workout only lasts 31 minutes. Show up a few minutes early to meet people and get yourself pumped up.

results.description:
Every week we will have a different prompt for our weekly photo project.  This week’s theme is How other's see you

Each week beginning early Monday morning, you can begin uploading your photos to our meetup album for the week’s theme.  The group won’t actually meet for this event, it’s an individual online challenge for each of you to get your creative juices flowing, share photos in the group, comment and critique each other’s shots, and above all have fun. 

Albums will remain open, so you can upload photos any time after that Monday morning start time but you’ll get the most feedback during the initial week the theme is posted.  You also don’t have to restrict yourself to photos taken during that week for the theme, they can be from past shoots you have done or the weekly prompt can be used to motivate you to shoot something new.

Please consider sharing your project photos with our other chapters on our Facebook group.
results.name: Weekly Photo Project - How other's see you

results.description:
PGConf US 2016 is a non-profit conference hosted run by the: United States PostgreSQL Association . 

This conference is part of the effort to grow the PostgreSQL community by increasing awareness and providing the appropriate training and resources to further PostgreSQL adoption.

• Register for Conference

• Register for 20th Anniversary Party 

(Attendees to conference do not need party ticket)

The Vision

The goal of PGConf US is to sustain a regular PostgreSQL-focused conference to combine the focuses from the open-source and enterprises worlds to help promote awareness and usage of PostgreSQL through tutorials, case-studies, and opportunities to meet some of the best minds in the PostgreSQL community.


Learning


With expert speakers, structured breakouts, and fun activities, PGConf US 2016 provides an ideal environment to connect and learn from PostgreSQL veterans and other technology experts.


Community


We aim to serve as a model to help and support other local PostgreSQL user groups with providing similar conferences and programming.

results.description:
Hi Ladies!

Have you considered a career in eDiscovery?

Meet professionals across the eDiscovery industry from attorneys to litigation support at the ACEDS Conference in NYC, April 18-20, 2016, at the Grand Hyatt in midtown Manhattan.

Here is the conference link:


www.ediscoveryconference.com

Join hundreds of your colleagues in the heart of New York City this spring to advance your education and your career. Whether you are newly certified, an experienced practitioner or seeking CLE, the ACEDS conference has you covered. Our National conference assumes a basic level of eDiscovery experience and knowledge. Our sessions encourage panelists who may have different opinions on breaking issues to express them in session. Known as an interactive conference, attendees are encouraged to dialogue with the stellar panel of speakers assembled. From groundbreaking jurists to hardworking paralegals, our speakers and attendees place a high value on community, collaboration and conviviality. In addition to efficiencies in current practice and grappling with cutting edge eDiscovery issues, special sessions will be focused on employment, career advancement and emerging adjacent opportunities for technical legal people.

The Conference will feature:


• Over 30 eDiscovery expert speakers
• Panels discussing the hottest eDiscovery problems and solutions
• Multiple networking opportunities throughout the event
• And more

About ACEDS

The Association of Certified E-Discovery Specialists (ACEDS) is the member organization for professionals in the private and public sectors who work in the field of eDiscovery. ACEDS is building a community of eDiscovery specialists for the exchange of ideas, guidance, training and best practices, and offers eDiscovery certification. ACEDS has established the field’s first certification exam. Qualified candidates who pass a rigorous examination will earn the right to use the Certified E-Discovery Specialist (CEDS™) certification. Visit ACEDS.org to learn more.

Please stay tuned for more details, like discount passes etc!

For more information, contact: [masked]

PGConf US 2016 is a non-profit conference hosted run by the United States PostgreSQL Association as part of Database Month.


This conference is part of the effort to grow the PostgreSQL community by increasing awareness and providing the appropriate training and resources to further PostgreSQL adoption.

4-tracks over 2-days (plus a tutorial-day) with speakers from Amazon Web Services (AWS), EMC, Blackberry Mobiles (RIM), Open Source Consulting Group (OpenSCG) and many other world-class organizations, as well as the head-engineer/manager of one of the largest PostgreSQL installations in the world!

United States PostgreSQL Association Techie Youth is the official charity of PGConf US 2016. Supporters of Techie Youth (http://www.TechieYouth.org) are entitled to a 10% discount on PgConf registration using code TY10

Register for PgConf now at http://www.pgconf.us/2016/

results.description:
Join us Monday April 18th at 10am (RAIN OR SHINE) for our Meetups kick off meeting! This will be an opportunity to learn more about us, what we represent, what we do, and where we want to go! The community we are envisioning needs you to help it grow! Please feel free to bring a guest or two with you. They do not need to join the Meetup group yet, they may use the kick-off to see if we're a good fit for their lifestyle. Bottled water and light snacks will be served. Please be sure to RSVP for yourself as well as your guests so we can have an accurate headcount. If you are unable to attend please update your RSVP on our groups main page.

Our Kick Off Extravaganza will include:

One "Welcome Folder" per attendee full of health, fitness, and nutrition information; routes, parks and walking track info; copies of a fitness progress document for you to utilize as our walks begin; a goals and achievement guideline for you to start thinking about what you would like to gain from our walking group and some ways in which we can help and much more!

We will discuss some of our ideas to keep the group interested and motivated:

* Weekly themed emails
* A monthly newsletter
* A virtual bulletin board that will include local neighborhood walks, charity walks, walks for causes as well as upcoming themed walks for our group (relay races, buddy up/getting to know you)
* Recognition and incentives; certificates of achievement and a gift of recognition from the group organizers as members reach their milestones.
* We are interested in hearing additional thoughts and ideas from you all!

We will have Herbalife samples product/plan information, literature about Herbalife and product brochures for anyone who may be interested. This giveaway is 100% optional. If you do opt to take a sample package, there is no further obligation whatsoever.

We would love to have a group discussion with your input on topics such as: Do's and Don't's for our walks (ex. will earbuds be allowed for periods of time during the walk); what do we do in cases of inclement weather; what activities/meet ups outside of health and fitness would you be interested in.

We are a community driven initiative, your thoughts, ideas and input are encouraged and greatly appreciated!

Beginning Thursday, April 21st our Spring schedule will be in full affect!

Every Monday and Thursday we will meet at Little Bay Park (Whitestone entrance) at 10am

In addition to our weekly walks we will also include:

* Intro/Welcome for our new members
* Before & After stretching (approximately 5-10 minutes each)

Welcome to our growing community! Here's to a happy, healthy Spring!

results.description:
Two in a row! 

As part of the #jettechtalk series, we occasionally bring in an external speaker to teach us something new. This week, Mathias will be talking to us about his latest machine learning project! Join us! 

About Mathias

Mathias Brandewinder has been developing software on .NET for about 10 years, and loving every minute of it, except maybe for a few release days. His language of choice was C#, until he discovered F# and fell in love with it. He enjoys arguing about code and how to make it better, and gets very excited when discussing TDD or F#. His other professional interests include forecasting models, machine learning and applying math to solve business problems. Mathias is a Microsoft F# MVP and the founder of Clear Lines Consulting. He is based in San Francisco, blogs at www.brandewinder.com, and can be found on Twitter as @Brandewinder

ABSTRACT

Just like traditional applications development, machine learning involves writing code. One aspect where the two differ is the workflow. While software development follows a fairly linear process (design, develop, and deploy a feature), machine learning is a different beast. You work on a single feature, which is never 100% complete. You constantly run experiments, and re-design your model in depth at a rapid pace. Traditional tests are entirely useless. Validating whether you are on the right track takes minutes, if not hours.

In this talk, we will take the example of a Machine Learning competition we recently participated in, the Kaggle Home Depot competition, to illustrate what "doing Machine Learning" looks like. We will explain the challenges we faced, and how we tackled them, setting up a harness to easily create and run experiments, while keeping our sanity. We will also draw comparisons with traditional software development, and highlight how some ideas translate from one context to the other, adapted to different constraints.

results.name: Jet Tech Talk:  Agile experiments in Machine Learning, by Mathias Brandewinder

results.description:
Dropwizard is basically a light-weight package of stable, mature libraries from the Java ecosystem. It enables rapid and highly performant API’s to be developed quickly.

Dropwizard has out-of-the-box support for sophisticated configuration, application metrics, logging, operational tools, and much more, allowing you and your team to ship a production-quality web service in the shortest time possible.

With no performance tuning a single Dropwizard jar can handle 30,000 - 50,000 request a second and since you can spin up as many “Fat Jars” as you want it can be load balanced to handle much much more.

Together we will dive into how Dropwizard differs from enterprise java, how it compares against javascript and other languages/frameworks and take a look at some of it’s inner workings.

--

Luke has been programming since the age of 2. He got his Bachelor of Science in Computer Science from Plattsburgh State University. Luke has been a Java developer for 10+ years and is currently working as a Senior Enterprise Architect at InRhythm. He has previously worked at Razorfish, HBO, and Hewlett-Packard.

When not coding, Luke likes to write songs and play guitar with his rock and roll band. You may have also caught Luke’s son as Cole in “This Is Where I Leave You”. If you have ever used an Etch A Sketch - make sure to say thank you for his great uncle’s invention.
results.name: Building Light Deployment Free JSON API’s with Dropwizard - Luke Lappin

results.description:
Reserve early and save at http://tinyurl.com/jx44ppx

Do you know anyone who spends time during the workday fighting obstacles that get in the way of them doing their jobs? It could be processes that aren’t optimized, poor tools, team members who aren’t right for the job, managers who are reminiscent of the pointed-hair boss on Dilbert, or a host of other reasons. Solving that is going to be the focus of our April 18th meeting.

It’s been about 12 years since Bob Jarvis last presented at NY SPIN (Experiences Combining Extreme Programming (XP) with Six Sigma and CMMI). This time, he will be discussing something else which he’s passionate about – unlocking the potential of workers by removing the obstacles that get in the way of them doing their best work. Clearly this is partially a process issue, but there are several other key dimensions that also need to be addressed.

In this interactive session, Bob will provide a high-level walk-through of a framework to identify the real symptoms, an approach to presenting the results to management so they “get it,” and an implementation cycle to fix the root causes. For those who want to learn more, the details are available on his blog.

Brief Bio
Bob Jarvis has broad experience in quality improvement efforts, from his time in the U.S. Air Force, to executive positions in national consulting firms, his work as Chief Quality Officer at Instinet, his experience as a Master Black Belt at JP Morgan Chase, and his role as VP Quality Assurance at GSI Commerce (now eBay Enterprise). Most recently, Bob founded Quality Enablement LLC, established to help organizations, from senior management to individual contributors, identify and remove barriers to quality; and he is the author of the blog, “A Better Workplace …”
results.name: Enable Your Workers … and You’ll Be Amazed At What They Can Do (Bob Jarvis)

results.description:
We will power up the Major Welch, take in the sunset & socialize briefly at Perkins Tower, then descend on the AT.

We will meet in the main parking lot. If you are running late, you are welcome to catch up with the group if we have begun.

This is not a beginner hike. You should have some hiking experience and be getting regular exercise. While it is only four miles, there is significant elevation gain on the Major Welch.

Make sure you have a copy of the map, a headlamp, and minimum 2 liter of water. If you fall behind during the hike, you must be prepared to finish on your own. Faster hikers are not obligated to wait for slower hikers. Typically we meet at the parking lot and begin together. As we ascend, the group breaks off. We will do our best to reconvene at the peak and begin our descent together. The amount of time we spend at Perkins will depend upon the weather. You must feel comfortable hiking out on your own should you fall behind. We would love to have everyone join but due the nature of an evening event we can not make accommodations for those who are unable to hike independently. There is no sweep. If you are unsure whether or not this is for you, please email me with any questions.

Heavy rain cancels and would be determined that day if necessary.

Distance: about 4 miles

Gain: about 1200

Hike time: 2 - 3 hours

HUDSON VALLEY HIKER LEGAL DISCLAIMER & WAIVER OF LIABILITY

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

The Hudson Valley Hikers Club does not provide liability insurance for the protection of individuals who may participate in any of the events planned by the Organizer or Assistant Organizers.

This release extends and applies to, and also covers and includes, all unknown, unforeseen, unanticipated and unsuspected injuries, damages, loss and liability.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver. By signing up for this group or event you understand that you are attending all events AT YOUR OWN RISK. Organizers and Assistant

Organizers of this group are just that, we organize the events and hike together as friends. There are no leaders on these hikes, you are your own leader - This is YOUR hike

results.description:
Hi Party For a Cause Volunteer Group!


Its time for us New Yorkers to get out of winter hibernation and have some fun for a cause!!


GET-OUT-OF-HIBERNATION HAPPY HOUR!

When: Monday, April 18th @ 6PM - 8PM

Where: Ginger Man, 11 E36th St., in the back room


Please join us for complimentary apps and good company while you chat with other interested volunteers and current volunteers of Helene Marks Early Start Foundation (HMESF).


HMESF finds, fosters and funds early childcare education in communities who need our help most, especially in NYC's outer boroughs. We believe helping neighbors elevates our city community as a whole.


We'd love your help in areas of fundraising and strategic planning for HMESF. We look forward to meeting you and celebrating a good cause!


Please go to the back room and look for the area with yellow/purple balloons. And please RSVP on the meetup site so we can keep an eye out for you. See you soon! Looking forward!!

Melanie

results.description:
I am a Spanish native speaker and suggest we meet at Think Coffee to help you to improve your Spanish!

There is a maximum of 6 students per group and costs $10/person if more than 3 people come to the class and $15/person if 1 to 3 people come to the class.

My phone number is[masked] just in case you cannot find me.

Don´t sign up if you are not sure you can come.

The lesson lasts 1 hour.

Hasta pronto!

Beguinner level means: you are not able to speak without the help of the teacher, you just know really little common expresions. We will go thought the basics.

Intermediate level means: you can explain yourself with the help of the teacher, you can build up sentences but they are basic or you make mistakes on them. You have lacks of vocabulary and grammar.

Advanced level means: you are fluent in Spanish, you can explain yourself without a lof of problems. You know the vocabulary. Advanced students normally make gramatical mistakes when they talk and can forget some words, that is perfectly normal.
results.name: Spanish conversation Advanced. $10/person if more 3people or $15/p if less

results.description:
Come for the sheer joy of moving to the music, in a nurturing and supportive setting.

Whether you have never danced before or want to continue, this is a class for you.

The classes are one hour and half in length and provide quality instruction.

Ballet is one of the most healthy and intense forms of dance.
It can provide a complete full-body workout, increasing your flexibility, range of motion and strength.

It’s also a great alternative to aerobics.

The classes are on-going, join in anytime.

PRICES Walk-Ins: $20.
Package: $180 for a card of 10 classes (over a course of 6 months).
Talk to us about multiple class per week discount!

ABOUT THE INSTRUCTOR
Bruce Weitzmon is a choreographer, dancer and teacher. His work has been presented in the U.S.A. and Canada. Bruce was the director of the Theater Dance Center, a non-profit dance education and performance organization in Rockland County, founded in 1981. After many years directing TDC, he returned to New York City to teach. Now after more than 10 years there, he is returning to offer a weekly schedule of classes in Nyack, NY.

VISIT US ON FACEBOOK
For more about the Dancers’ Art class schedule, rates or any additional information please visit and like Dancers’ Art on Facebook at www.facebook.com/DancersArt or call[masked]-1973.
results.name: ADULT BALLET CLASS Level: Elementary

results.description:
That's right. After almost 2 decades in NYC, my family is moving to LA to start a new life out West. I thought long and hard about what to do with BKUX upon my departure. After a lot of conversations, we came up with a great solution.

Ive appointed a new team to run BKUX. Chris, Talia, Sunil & Teena. We have huge plans for the future of BKUX and the community we've all created in the last few years. Lou, Eduardo, Donna, Anders and myself will still be involved, just in a different capacity.

We will roll out details as time goes on. Ill just say a lot of exciting ideas are in the works.

I hope to see you all on the 18th and thanks for everything you've done to make BKUX awesome for all these years!
results.how_to_find_us: We're the large group in the middle.
results.name: Say goodbye to Ian and hello to the new BKUX team

JC Writers writing marathons are about setting loose your inner writer-athlete and really getting some words down. You’ll be amazed at how much you can get done when you leave the distractions of home and spend a few hours in the company of other writers pounding away at their novels, short stories, screenplays and other works. The ensuring endorphins of accomplishment and sense of community with other writers will make you feel like you just ran a marathon, minus the jello-legs and carb cravings!!

Note: There is free parking for Zeppelin Hall!!

results.description:
Join Nafisa Sharriff and the West African Dance Family for Free Classes every Monday and Wednesday evening from 6pm – 8pm at Countee Cullen/PS 194. located on 144th Street between Adam Clayton Powell and Frederick Douglas Blvds in Harlem, NY. 

Summer Hours: 5pm – 7pm (July and August only).

Nafisa Sharriff is a Master Teacher and Choreographer of Traditional West African Folklore from the Old Malian Empire. She is the recipient of the 1996 Ethnic Dance Award and numerous Community Service commemorations. Throughout her illustrious career Nafisa performed with Stevie Wonder, Whitney Houston, Spike Lee, TC Carson, C&C Music Factory, The Chuck Davis Dance Company & The Kairaba West African Dance Company. Her television credits include performances on the Richard Pryor Show, Dance Black America & Positively Black.

Facebook Page : Twitter

Nyeek Drinks are our game nights at Amity Hall. They're pretty regular, but always check the listings before coming in case we have to cancel or change dates.

Most of the places we play at don't charge us a rental fee. So please keep in mind not to bring outside food or drink, to purchase something from the establishment and to be respectful of the space in general.

There is a game night special that runs from 5 PM to 11 PM for people playing games. In addition to $5.00 drafts on select beers it is also $10.00 for sliders, wings, chicken strips, nachos or traditional pizza. Please note that it $10.00 for the individual items, not for all five.

results.description:
In this 2-hr fashion photography class our experienced instructors will assist you in exploring composition, studio and outdoor lighting, industry trends and the use of Photoshop in fashion images. Students are encouraged to bring fashion images to be analyzed and broken down during class time. Bring your camera with fresh batteries, and it's manuals if at hand. 

Requirements: Basic knowledge of aperture & shutter-speed are highly recommended but not necessary. Note, if you are looking to learn Studio Photography only, please refer to our ""Studio & Lighting seminar""

NOTE: Please only RSVP if you are certain you can make the event. There is a limited number of seats available and each RSVP gets one. Please cancel as soon as know you cannot make it so the next person the waiting list can attend. Thank you!

See you there!

Join The Empire Steppers for Chicago Steppin' Mondays at the Steam House


Chicago Stepping is a partner dance to soulful music.


STEAM HOUSE RESTAURANT & LOUNGE
128 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon, NY 10550

Bring your dancing shoes and appetite. The Steam House has great signature dishes. American & Caribbean Cuisine - Steam, Fried & broiled Sea Food and specialty drinks. 

TIME: 6pm - 10pm
